translation.en: [Update] As members of SEBIN searched Diaz's and Soto's home, Luz Mely Reyes reported live from the scene.
translation.yo: [Ìròyìn tó tẹ̀wá lọ́wọ́] Luz Mely Reyes tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà ṣe ojúu rẹ̀, fi tó wa létí nípa bí àwọn Agbófinró SEBIN ṣe yẹ ilée Díaz pẹ̀lú ilée Soto náà wò.

translation.en: The SNTP also reported the incident:
translation.yo: Ìsọ̀kan àwọn Oníròyìn náà fẹ ọ̀rọ̀ náà lójú:

translation.en: URGENT At this time, 3:30 am, a commission from the Intelligence Forces arrives to journalist and human rights activist Luis Carlos Díaz's home, missing since 5:30 pm #WhereIsLuisCarlos
translation.yo: NÍ KÍÁKÍÁ Ní dédé àsìkò yìí, ní dédé agogo 3:00 òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù, ìgbìmọ̀ láti àjọ Amúninípá dé ilé oníròyìn àti ajà-fún- ẹ̀tọ́ọ ọmọ ènìyàn Luis Carlos Díaz, tí ó ti di ẹni àwátì láti agogo 5:30 ìrọ̀lẹ́ #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.

translation.en: Other human rights and freedom of speech organizations joined the campaign through #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Where is Luis Carlos?) which is, at the moment, a trending topic in Venezuela's twittosphere.
translation.yo: Àwọn ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti àjọ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ náà darapọ̀ mọ ìpolongo yìí pẹ̀lú #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Níbo ni Luis Carlos wà?), tí ó jẹ́ pé, ní báyìí, ni àkọlé tí ó gbajúmọ̀ ní orí ìkànnì ayélujára Twitter ti Orílẹ̀ Èdè Venezuela.

translation.en: Díaz is a journalist and a human rights and freedom of speech advocate who is well known and highly appreciated in Venezuela and abroad for his commentary and criticism of the government of Nicolas Maduro.
translation.yo: Díaz jẹ́ ajábọ̀ ìròyìn àti a-jà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́-ọmọ ènìyàn tí ó jẹ́ ògbólógbòó ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ tí wọ́n sì mọ ìṣe rẹ̀ fún un l'órílẹ̀ èdè Venezuela àti òkè òkun fún ìdásọ́rọ̀ àti ìtakò ìjọba Nicholas Maduro.

translation.en: He has long worked with Soto producing web-based video and radio programs focused on politics and human rights in Venezuela.
translation.yo: Ó ti tó ìgbà díẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìyàwó rẹ̀ àti olùdásọ́rọ̀ òṣèlú tí ó gbajúmọ̀ n nì, Naky Soto, tí wọn sì ń ṣe ìgbéjáde àwọn fídíò àti ètò Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ lórí ayélujára èyí tí ó dá lórí ìṣèlú àti ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn ní Venezuela.

translation.en: He has also worked as an educator and promoter of the creation of citizen media spaces and independent media projects.
translation.yo: Ó ti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí akọ́ni àti olùgbé-lárúgẹ ìdásílẹ̀ àyè ọ̀tọ̀ fún àwọn ará ìlú àti àwọn àkànṣe eto ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ tí kò lọ́wọ́ ìjọ̀ba nínú.

translation.en: Díaz has also been part of the Global Voices community for more than a decade.
translation.yo: Díaz tún jẹ́ olùkópa nínú ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé fún ọdún mẹ́wàá.

translation.en: To me, Luis Carlos is a brilliant person, well versed in information and networks in this chaotic Venezuela of ours.
translation.yo: Lọ́dọ̀ tèmi, Luis Carlos jẹ́ onílàákàyè ẹ̀dá kan, ó gbọ́njú nínú ìròyìn gbígbà àti ìkànsì-ara-ẹni nínú Venezuela ti wa yìí tí kò fara rọ.

translation.en: He has been able to make links with society (from criticism to cultural spaces) #WhereIsLuisCarlos.
translation.yo: Ó ti ṣe àwárí ìjápọ̀ nínú ìlú (láti ìtakò sí ibi ìṣẹ̀ṣe) #NiboniLuisCarlosWa.

translation.en: Just a few days prior to his disappearance, the state-affiliated media program Con el Mazo Dando showed a video clip of a recent broadcast of Diaz.
translation.yo: Láàrin ọjọ́ péréte tó ṣíwájú ìpòóráa rẹ̀, ètò ìkàn-sára- ẹni ti ìjọba Con el Mazo Dando ṣàfihàn fídíò tí Díaz sọ̀rọ̀ nínúu rẹ̀.

translation.en: The program's host, politician Diosdado Cabello, insinuated that Diaz had helped to orchestrate the nationwide power outage that had Venezuelans living in the dark for more than 24 hours on March 7 and 8.
translation.yo: Atọ́kùn ètò ọ̀hún, olóṣèlú Diosdado Cabello, rò kàn pé Díaz lọ́wọ́ sí ìfẹ̀hónú hàn àìsí ináa mọ̀nàmọ̀nà tí ò lọ jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè èyí tí ó mú kí àwọn ọmọ Venezuela máa gbé nínú òkùnkùn fún ó lé ní wákàtí mẹ́rin lé lógún lọ́jọ́ 7 àti 8 Oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà

translation.en: There is no evidence to support this.
translation.yo: Kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó fi ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀.

translation.en: It's been been seven hours since Luis Carlos Díaz has gone missing.
translation.yo: Wákàtí méje ti ré kọjá lọ tí Luis Carlos Díaz ti di àwátì.

translation.en: [Díaz] is a journalist for Unión Radio Noticias and he's a human rights activist.
translation.yo: [Díaz] jẹ́ oníròyìn fún ilé iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Unión Radio Noticias , ó sì tún jẹ́ ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn.

translation.en: We're at the SEBIN headquarters and they deny having him [in custody there] #WhereIsLuisCarlos
translation.yo: Àwa ní olú ilé iṣẹ́ẹ SEBIN headquarters àti pé wọ́n ní àwọn kò ní í [ní àhámọ́ àwọn] #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.

translation.en: [Update: they later confirmed Diaz was in custody]
translation.yo: [Ìròyìn tí ó tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́: they wọ́n pàpà jẹ́wọ́ wípé [Diaz wà ní akolóo wọn]

translation.en: Journalist Vladimir Villegas denounced that he had been detained by government forces:
translation.yo: Akọ̀ròyìn Vladimir Villegas sọ wípé kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ́ wípé ìjọba ni ó fi ọwọ́ agbára mú u:

translation.en: We've been informed that @Unionradionet journalist Luis Carlos Díaz, has been detained by State's security forces.
translation.yo: radionet Luis Carlos Díaz, ti wà nínú àtìmọ́lé agbófinró Ìlú.

translation.en: We express our concern for his physical integrity.
translation.yo: A bá a kẹ́dùn ipò tí ó wà.

translation.en: We demand any information of his whereabouts and respect for his human rights.
translation.yo: A béèrè fún ìtọ́sọ́nà nípa mímọ ibi tí ó wà, àti ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn-an rẹ̀.

translation.en: The Global Voices community stands in solidarity with Luis Carlos, his family, and all other independent journalists working to hold power to account in Venezuela.
translation.yo: Ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé dúró ṣinṣin pẹ̀lú Luis Carlos, ẹbíi rẹ̀, àti oníròyìn aládàáṣiṣẹ́ gbogbo àwọn tí ó ń mú ìjọba ṣe bí ó ti yẹ ní Venezuela.

translation.en: We wish for his safe and speedy return, and will continue to update this story as it develops.
translation.yo: À ń retíi rẹ̀ kí ó dé kíákíá ní àlàáfíà ara àti ẹ̀mí, a ó máa gbé àwọn ìròyìn síta nípa ìròyìn yìí bí ó ba ṣe ń tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́.

translation.en: Nigeria's social media bill will obliterate online freedom of expression
translation.yo: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà yóò pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà

translation.en: The draconian bill will legalize internet shutdowns in Nigeria
translation.yo: Ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò fi àṣẹ fún ìṣánpa ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríàj

translation.en: Senator Mohammed Sani Musa is the sponsor of the social media bill. Screenshot from Channel Television You Tube video.
translation.yo: Aṣojú Mohammed Sani Musa ni agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà. Àwòrán àgékù láti ibùdó Channel Television You Tube .

translation.en: On November 20, the Protection from Internet Falsehoods and Manipulation of other Related Matters Bill 2019, known as the "social media bill", sponsored by Senator Mohammed Sani Musa, sailed through a second reading.
translation.yo: Lọ́jọ́ 20 oṣù Belu, Ìwé Àbádòfin tí ó fi Ààbò fún Irọ́ àti Màkàrúrù tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ ọn ti ọdún-un 2019, tí a mọ̀ sí "ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà", tí Aṣojú kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Sani Musa ṣe agbátẹrùu rẹ̀, ti di kíkà nínú ìgbìmọ̀ fún ìgbà kejì.

translation.en: The social media bill aims to curb online falsehoods and mis- and disinformation.
translation.yo: Èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ni láti dẹ́kun àwọn àhesọ àti gbólóhùn tí kì í ṣe òtítọ́ lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere.

translation.en: However, the real intent is not regulation, but rather, the annihilation of online freedom of expression, criminalization of government criticism and legalization of internet shutdowns in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Bí-ó-ti-lẹ̀-jẹ́-wípé, kì í ṣe láti fi òfin de ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà ni ìwé àbádòfin náà dá lé lórí, àmọ́ ṣá, ó máa pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára, ìsọ alátakò ìjọba di ọ̀daràn àti fífi àtìpà ẹ̀rọ ayélujára fúngbà díẹ̀ sínú ìwé òfin.

translation.en: A similar bill was beaten dead in its track in 2016.
translation.yo: Àtẹ̀pa bí erín bá tẹ koríko ni àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà tẹ irú ìwé àbádòfin báyìí pa ní ọdún-un 2016.

translation.en: Any form of government criticism is a crime
translation.yo: Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ni bí o bá gbó ìjọba lẹ́nu (tako ìjọba)

translation.en: This bill aims to "[prevent] the transmission of false statements or declaration of facts in Nigeria", according to Section 1a.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 1A ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin yìí ni láti "[máà jẹ́] kí ìgbéjáde ọ̀rọ̀ tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan nínú tàbí èyí tí ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ kò f'ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀ tó ó jáde ní Nàìjíríà".

translation.en: It will ban the dissemination statements likely to be "prejudicial" to Nigeria, including subjects like public health, public safety, "public tranquility or public finances" and Nigeria's "friendly relations with other countries".
translation.yo: Yóò yọ ọwọ́ kílàńkó àwọn àtẹ̀jáde irọ́ tí ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà sí "ìyọnu", láwo láì gbàgbée àwọn ọ̀ràn bíi ètò ìlera gbogboògbò, ààbòo gbogboògbò, "ìbalẹ̀-ọkàn-an gbogboògbò tàbí ìṣúná owóo gbogboògbò" àti "àwọn ìbáṣepọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè mìíràn".

translation.en: The bill will also "detect, control and safeguard against coordinated misuse of online accounts and bots", according to Section 1c.
translation.yo: Abala 1c sọ bí ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò ṣe "mú, ṣàkóso àti fi ààbò bo ìlònílòkulò àwọn ìṣàmúlò àti ẹ̀rọ adánìkanṣiṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára".

translation.en: In other words, everything is permissible to monitor and control in the proposed law — under the guise of fighting false information.
translation.yo: Ní àlàyé síwájú sí i, kò sí ohun tí ojú òfin tuntun náà kò leè tó bí ó bá ti jẹ́ lórí ayélujára — lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń gbógun ti àhesọ àti irọ́ pọ́nbẹ́lẹ́.

translation.en: The social media bill is omniscient since it will be binding for every Nigerian citizen, regardless of residence or geographic location, as long as the ambiguous "false statement of fact" is transmitted within the country.
translation.yo: Ọ̀run ń ya bọ̀ ni ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà, kò yọ ẹnìkan sílẹ̀, gbogbo ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà ni yóò bá, kò kan agbègbè tàbí ibi tí ènìyàn fi ṣe ibùgbé, máà ṣe é l'oògùn máà mọ́, ọwọ́ àwọn ológìnní ojú tólé ojú tóko ni "gbólóhùn irọ́ tí kò ní ẹ̀rí" tí ó bá gba òpópónà ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere Nàìjíríà yóò bọ́ sí.

translation.en: Section 3a to b(i) of the social media bill states that:
translation.yo: Abala 3a sí b(i) ti ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà sọ wípé:

translation.en: A person must not do any act in or outside Nigeria in order to transmit in Nigeria a statement knowing or having reasons to believe that it is a false statements of fact; and the transmission of the statement in Nigeria is likely to be, prejudicial to the security of Nigeria or any part of Nigeria.
translation.yo: Ẹnikẹ́ni kò gbọdọ̀ wu ìwà kíwà kan nínú tàbí lẹ́yìn odi Nàìjíríà láti tari gbólóhùn tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan tí a kò leè fi ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ síta; àti àgbésórí afẹ́fẹ́ ayélujára gbólóhùn t'ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà síta bí ọmọ ọjọ́ mẹ́jọ nípa ti ààbò ìlú.

translation.en: The nebulous "national security" excuse is used to justify the trumping of free expression.
translation.yo: Ọ̀ràn-an ti "ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè" ni orí Èṣù tí òfin náà dúró lé láti pa ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ mọ́.

translation.en: But it does not stop there, the Nigerian government is always right and cannot be criticized.
translation.yo: Àmọ́ kò tán síbẹ̀, kò sí ẹní tó lè tako ìjọba Nàìjíríà tàbí gbó o lẹ́nu nítorí kì í ṣ'àṣìṣe.

translation.en: According to Section 3b(vi), any statement that diminishes “public confidence in the performance of any duty or function of, in the exercise of any power of the government” is prohibited.
translation.yo: Ní Abala 3b(vi), gbólóhùn tí ó bá yẹpẹrẹ “ojúṣe tàbí ìṣe, tí ó jẹ́ ti ìjọba lójú ará ìlú” kò leè la orí ayélujára kọjá.

translation.en: According to Section 3b(v), this applies to any statement that: "incites feelings of enmity, hatred, directed at persons or ill-will between different groups of persons".
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 3b(v) ti ṣe fi hàn, èyí ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú gbólóhùn tí ó: "fa ìmúnilọ́tàá, tí a sọ sí ẹnìkan tàbí ìtara láàárín àwọn ènìyàn".

translation.en: This is dangerous because it leaves regulators open to contradictory interpretations that could be abused by political actors.
translation.yo: Èyí léwu nítorí ó fi àyè gba àwọn onípò àṣẹ láti lo agbára nílòkulò.

translation.en: Who defines and approves what incites feelings of hatred?
translation.yo: Ta ní í sọ bóyá gbólóhùn kan lè fa rògbòdìyàn?

translation.en: It means that seeking transparency or even daring to hold a politician accountable could be declared hateful.
translation.yo: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wípé lílo inú kan tàbí mímú àwọn olóṣèlúu mú ìléríi wọn ṣe lè já sí ìkórìíra lójúu wọn.

translation.en: The punishment upon conviction for any provisions of the bill is a fine that ranges between 200,000 and 10 million naira [about $556 to $28,000 United States dollars], imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or both.
translation.yo: Owó ìtanràn fún ẹni tí ilé ẹjọ́ bá dá lẹ́bi tó láàárín ẹgbẹ̀rún 200 àti ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 10 owó naira [tí ó tó $556 sí $28,000 owó orílẹ̀ èdèe United States], ìtìmọ́lé fún ọdún mẹ́ta tàbí méjèèjì.

translation.en: Police licensed to shut down the internet
translation.yo: Àṣẹ fún Àjọ Agbófinró láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélujára pa fúngbà díẹ̀

translation.en: The social media bill also grants the government unlimited power to switch off the internet, through the "Access Blocking Order" as contained in Section 12, number 3:
translation.yo: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà fún ìjọba lágbára bí ó ṣe hù wọ́n láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere pa nígbàkúùgbà tí ó bá lérò wípé ó tọ́, nípasẹ̀ "Àṣẹ Ìdígàgá Ìráyè" láti lo ayélujára bí ó ti ṣe wà ní Abala 12, òǹkaye 3:

translation.en: The Law Enforcement Department may direct the NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – the regulatory agency for the telecommunication industry] to order the internet access service provider to take reasonable steps to disable access by end-users in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Ẹ̀ka Agbófinró leè fi àṣẹ fún Àjọ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Nàìjíríà NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – tí ó ń ṣe bòńkárí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá] láti pa á láṣẹ fún apèsè àyè sí ìlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára kí ó gbé ìgbésẹ̀ lójú ẹsẹ̀ tí ò ní mú àwọn òǹlò rí àyè lo ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: Internet service providers must comply with this blocking order or risk upon conviction a fine within the range of 5 to 10 million naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].
translation.yo: Àwọn apèsè ayélujára gbọdọ̀ tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá yìí tàbí kí wọ́n ó sanwó ìtanràn tí ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 5 sí 10 owó naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].

translation.en: In addition, the bill under consideration indemnifies the internet service providers from any "civil or criminal liability" incurred from a lawsuit brought against them for "complying to any access blocking order", according to section 12, number 5.
translation.yo: Ní àfikún, ìwé àbádòfin náà fi àrídájú ààbò bo àwọn apèsè iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tí kò ní mú wàhálà "ará ìlú tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ " tí kò bá à lè jáde láti ìdájọ́ kan tí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá pè wọ́n fúnopé "wọ́n tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá ìráyé" sí ayélujára, ìyẹn bí abala 12, òǹkaye 5 ṣe fi lélẹ̀.

translation.en: The human rights violations get murkier because the law grants the police a legal license to command an access-blocking order at whim.
translation.yo: Ìtẹ́rí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn náà ṣ'ókùnkùn sí i nítorí wípé òfin náà gba àwọn ọlọ́pàá láyè lábẹ́ òfin láti pa àṣẹ ìdígàgá-àyè bí ó ti ṣe hù wọ́n.

translation.en: Section 15a states that only the "initiative" of the police in face of "overwhelming sufficing evidence" is needed to cancel an internet shutdown in the country.
translation.yo: Abala 15a sọ wípé “iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ” ọlọ́pàá ní àsìkò "ìṣèwádìí ẹ̀rí tó dájú" jẹ́ kókó láti fagilé ìṣánpá ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

translation.en: Consequently, "no appeal may be made to the High Court" [Section 13(2)] by any party to revoke such a ban without first applying to the police to revoke an existing blocking order.
translation.yo: Ní ìparí, “kò sí àyè fún ẹjọ́ọ kò tèmi lọ́rùn ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga” [Abala 13(2)] tí eẹnikẹ́ni lè fi yẹ ìdígàgá sílẹ̀ láì máà kọ́kọ́ tọ ọlọ́pàá lọ láti fagilé òfin ìdígàgá náà.

translation.en: The implications of this are obvious — no one can resort to the courts for redress in the face of this violation while the blocking order persists.
translation.yo: Ipa èyí hàn gbàgàdà — ẹnikẹ́ni kò ní leè gba ilé ẹjọ́ lọ fún ìgbèjà ìfẹ̀tọ́ ẹni dunni yìí tí ìdígàgá náà ṣì wà.

translation.en: The lawmakers behind the social media bill
translation.yo: Àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin tí ó wà lẹ́yìn ìwé àbádòfin ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà

translation.en: Three lawmakers seem to be the arrowhead of the bill in the Senate, the upper house of Nigeria’s parliament: Mohammed Sani Musa (the sponsor of the bill), Abba Moro and Elisha Abbo.
translation.yo: Àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin mẹ́ta kan ni ó gbé ìwé àbádòfin náà sórí nínú ìgbìmọ̀, ilé ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà: Mohammed Sani Musa (agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin), Abba Moro àti Elisha Abbo.

translation.en: Mohammed Sani Musa’s company, Activate Technologies Limited, supplied the Permanent Voter Cards (PVCs) machine used for the 2019 general elections, while he was the candidate of the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) for Niger East Senatorial district, according to the investigate outlet, Premium Times.
translation.yo: Ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ Mohammed Sani Musa, Activate Technologies Limited, ni ó kó ẹ̀rọ Ìwé-pélébé Ìdìbò Alálòpẹ́ (PVCs) tí a lò fún ìbò ọdún-un 2019, nígbà tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíjedupò lábẹ́ ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu tí ó ń tukọ̀ ètò ìṣèlú lọ́wọ́ All Progressives Congress (APC) fún Aṣojú Ìlà-Oòrùn Niger, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé iṣẹ́ aṣèwádìí, Premium Times ṣe tẹ̀ ẹ́ jáde.

translation.en: This is an allegation that the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) admitted.
translation.yo: Àjọ Elétò (INEC) gba ẹ̀sùn náà mọ́ra.

translation.en: Musa’s conflict of interest raised some doubts about the true independence of Nigeria’s election umpire in the last election.
translation.yo: Ọ̀ràn yìí fi hàn pé àwọn alákòóso ìbò tí ó kọjá kò ṣiṣẹ́ láì lọ́wọ́ àwọn alágbára ń'nú.

translation.en: Ishaku Elisha Abbo of the opposition People’s Democratic Party (PDP) is a senator representing the Adamawa North Senatorial District in Adamawa State, in northeast Nigerian.
translation.yo: Ishaku Elisha Abbo ti ẹgbẹ́ alátakò People’s Democratic Party (PDP) jẹ́ aṣojú tí ó ń ṣojú Ẹkùn-un Àríwá Adamawa ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Adamawa, ní ìlà-oòrùn àríwá orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: In July 2019, in the presence of a police officer, Abbo assaulted a female staff member in an adult sex toy store in Abuja.
translation.yo: Nínú oṣù Agẹmọ 2019, ní ìṣojú ọlọ́pàá, Abbo ṣe àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú òṣìṣẹ́bìnrin kan nínú ìsọ̀ ohun ìbálòpọ̀ ní olú-ìlú Nàìjíríà ní Abuja.

translation.en: After a video of the assault went viral on social media, Abbo offered a public apology.
translation.yo: Lẹ́yìn tí àwòrán càṣemáṣe náà fọ́n ká sórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà, Abbo offered mọ ìwàa rẹ̀ lẹ́bí, ó sì bẹ̀bẹ̀.

translation.en: Abba Moro, also with the PDP, is the senator representing Benue South district, northcentral Nigeria.
translation.yo: Abba Moro, tí í ṣe ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP, ni aṣojú fún ẹ̀ka Gúúsù Benue, àárín gbùngbùn àríwá Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: On March 15, 2014, Moro, as minister of interior, was responsible for the Nigerian Immigration Recruitment tragedy in which about 6 million Nigerian youths who applied for 4,000 vacant positions in Nigerian Immigration Service were forced to assemble in various recruitment locations in the country.
translation.yo: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún-un 2014, Moro, tí í ṣe ọ̀gá pátápátá ètò abélé, ló wà nídìí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ abanilọ́kànjẹ́ Ìgbanisíṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́langba tí ó tó bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 6 tó fẹ́ àyè iṣẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún 4 tí ó ṣí sílẹ̀ nínú iléeṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ Aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí wọ́n kóra jọ níbi orísìírísìí jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

translation.en: The resulting stampede due to overcrowding led to about 20 deaths and multiple injuries.
translation.yo: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ó burúkú jáì náà tí ó ṣekú pa ogún ènìyàn àti ìpalára fún ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn.

translation.en: Moro was a recipient of part of the application fees paid by the job-seekers amounting to 675 million naira [about $1.8 million USD].
translation.yo: Moro gbà nínú of owó ìwáṣẹ̀ tí àwọn awáṣẹ́ san tí ó ń lọ bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 675 owóo naira [ $1.8 USD].

translation.en: Moro not only enriched himself but also bypassed the extant procurement laws for the Immigration Service.
translation.yo: Moro kó owó sápòo rẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ó fo òfin ìgbanǹkan Aṣọ́bodè dá.

translation.en: "No need for silence, fear or self-pity" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill!
translation.yo: "Kò nílò ìdákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, ìbẹ̀rù bojo tàbí ìkáàánú-araẹni" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill!

translation.en: Using the hashtag #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, Nigerian netizens took to Twitter to express their collective indignation:
translation.yo: Nípa lílo àmì #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà bọ́ sóríi Twitter láti sọ èrò ọkàn-an wọn:

translation.en: In a statement, Amnesty International condemned the use of "laws to justify human rights violations" because it will not only stop Nigerians "from speaking their minds" but will also "send them to jail for doing so".
translation.yo: Nínú gbólóhùn kan, Amnesty International fajúro sí lílo "àwọn òfin tí ó ń fìdìí ìfojú ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn gbolẹ̀ múlẹ̀ " nítorí pé kò ní pa àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà lẹ́nu mọ́ "láti máà sọ èrò ọkàn-an wọn" tí yóò sì tún "rán wọn lọ s'ẹ́wọ̀n fún wípé wọ́n ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ ".

translation.en: The parliament, under the pretext of curbing mis- and disinformation, is considering the enactment of a draconian law.
translation.yo: Lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń dẹ́kun gbólóhùn irọ́ àti ọ̀rọ̀ àhesọ, ń gbèrò ìṣòfin tí kò ní ìfẹ́ ará ìlú lọ́kàn.

translation.en: Ironically, the greatest propagators of false information online are political actors.
translation.yo: Ó jẹ́ ohun ìyàlẹ́nu, àwọn olóṣèlúu ló léwájú níbi ká gbé gbólóhùn irọ́ sórí ayélujára.

translation.en: Both Nigeria's ruling and main opposition parties turned Twitter into a minefield of ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 presidential elections.
translation.yo: Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu tí ó ń jẹ lọ́wọ́ àti ẹgbẹ́ alátakò gbòógì sọ Twitter di pápá ogun fa ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá, ìròyìn tí kò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀tàn lásìkò ìdìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019.

translation.en: Read more:
translation.yo: Kà síwájú sí i:

translation.en: Social media propelled ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during the Nigerian elections
translation.yo: Ẹ̀rọ alátagbà fa ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá, ìròyìn tí kò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀tàn lásìkò ìdìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019

translation.en: Twitter was a minefield of false information during the 2019 Nigerian elections
translation.yo: Twitter di pápá ogun fún gbólóhùn irọ́ lásìkò ìdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 2019

translation.en: In these troubling times of freedom of expression in Nigeria, the wise charge from American writer Toni Morrison evokes hope:
translation.yo: Ní àkókò bíi ti òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní Nàìjíríà tí a wà yìí, ọ̀rọ̀ ọlọ́pọlọ láti ẹnu òǹkọ̀wé orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Toni Morrison tí ó mú ìrétí dání:

translation.en: This is precisely the time when artists go to work. There is no time for despair, no place for self-pity, no need for silence, no room for fear.
translation.yo: ‎Èyí ni ìgbà tí àwọn ayàwòrán ń ṣiṣẹ́. Kò sáyé fún ìsọ̀rètínù, kò sáyé fún ìkáàánú-ara, kò nílò ìdákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, kò sí àyè fún ìbẹ̀rù bojo.

translation.en: We speak, we write, we do language.
translation.yo: A sọ, a kọ, a p'èdè.

translation.en: The bill is currently at its second reading in the Senate. To become law, it will need to move to committee stage where legislators will review it.
translation.yo: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ti jẹ́ kíkà ní ìgbà kejì nínú ìgbìmọ̀ Aṣojú-ṣòfin.

translation.en: The committee presents its report to Parliament, the bill is debated, a clean copy is re-presented to the Senate for a final vote and then, there's the presidential assent.
translation.yo: Kí ó tó di òfin, ó gbọdọ̀ gba ìgbìmọ̀ kan tí àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin yóò yẹ̀ ẹ́ wò. Ìgbìmọ̀ọtẹ̀ẹ́kótó náà yóò sì jábọ̀ àbájáde àyẹ̀wòo rẹ̀ fún Ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà, láti gbé e yẹ̀ wò, tí wọn yóò tẹ òmíràn jáde fún àyẹ̀wò tí ó kẹ́yìn, kí ààrẹ ó tó bu ọwọ́ lù ú.

translation.en: The Parliament must be hard-pressed to throw out the social media bill in its entirety.
translation.yo: A gbọdọ̀ fajú ro sí ìgbésẹ̀ Ìgbìmọ̀ kí wọ́n ba ju ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà dànù sígbó.

translation.en: This is because Africa’s most populous country will slide smoothly into full dictatorship once freedom of expression has been extinguished.
translation.yo: Nítorí orílẹ̀ èdèe tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ yóò yẹ̀ gẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ìjọba ìfipámúnisìn ní kété tí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ bá di títẹ̀ bọlẹ̀.

translation.en: Tanzania high court upholds ruling to end child marriage despite attempts to repeal it
translation.yo: Ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania pa á láṣẹ fún ìfòpinsí ìsoyìgì láàárín àgbàlagbà àti ọmọdé láì wo ti ìgbésẹ̀ ìmúpadàa rẹ̀

translation.en: "This is the best decision the court has ever made"
translation.yo: "Èyí ni ìpinnu tí ó dára jù lọ tí ilé-ẹjọ́ yóò ṣe"

translation.en: Schoolgirls in Tanzania pose for a photo on July 10, 2007. Photo by Fanny Schertzer, used with permission via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
translation.yo: Àwọn Ọmọiléèwé ọmọdébìnrin ní Tanzania dúró fún àwòrán lọ́jọ́ 10 oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un, 2007. Fanny Schertzer ni ó ya àwòrán, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ láti Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.

translation.en: In October 2019, Tanzania's high court upheld the landmark 2016 ruling that increased the minimum age of marriage for girls and boys to 18.
translation.yo: Nínú oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019, ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania ṣe ìdímú ṣinṣin ìdájọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí ó pàṣẹ ó kéré jù, ọmọbìnrin àti ọmọkùnrin gbọdọ̀ pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún kí ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó.

translation.en: The Tanzanian government attempted to repeal this decision, claiming that girls mature earlier and marriage is a form of protection for pregnant young women, and should, therefore, be allowed to marry earlier than 18.
translation.yo: Àjọ ọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania gbéègbésẹ̀ láti ṣe ìmúpadà ìpinnu yìí, nítorí wípé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin ń yára bàlágà àti wípé ààbò ni ìgbéyàwó jẹ́ fún ọ̀dọ́bìnrin aláboyún.

translation.en: But on October 23, 2019, the Tanzanian government lost its appeal and the high court ruling remains: The marriage age for both males and females is 18, reinforcing the ban on child marriage in Tanzania.
translation.yo: Àmọ́ ní ọjọ́ 23 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019, ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania pàdánù ẹjọ́ọ kòtẹ́milọ́rùnun rẹ̀ tí àṣẹ ilé ẹjọ́ gíga ṣì dúró: akọ àtabo gbọdọ̀ pé ọjọ́ orí méjìdínlógún kí wọn ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó, tí èyí sì ń fi agbára kún ìgbẹ́sẹ̀ ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania.

translation.en: According to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), Tanzania has one of the highest prevalence rates of child marriage in the world.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) ti ṣe wí, Tanzania ni ìsoyìgì ọmọdé pọ̀ sí jù lọ lágbàáyé.

translation.en: Netizens were quick to express their delight over the ruling.
translation.yo: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára ṣíra láti fi ìdùnnúu wọn hàn lóríi ìdájọ́ náà.

translation.en: Some congratulated Rebeca Z. Gyumi, the petitioner and respondent behind this case.
translation.yo: Àwọn kan kí Rebeca Z. Gyumi, aláfisùn àti ẹni tí ó lé wájú nínú ọ̀ràn ìsoyìgì àwọn ọmọdé náà.

translation.en: Gyumi is the founder and executive director of Msichana Initiative (Young Woman Initiative), a Tanzanian nongovernmental organization that empowers girls through education.
translation.yo: Gyumi ni olùdásílẹ̀ àti alákòóso àgbà Msichana Initiative (Ètò fún àwọn Ọ̀dọ́mọbìnrin), iléeṣẹ́ tí kì í ṣe tìjọba tí ó ń ró àwọn ọmọdébìnrin lágbára nípasẹ̀ ti ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé.

translation.en: The fight to end child marriage in Tanzania
translation.yo: Ìgbésẹ̀ láti fòpin sí ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania

translation.en: In 2016, Gyumi challenged the constitutionality of the Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) that allowed females under the age of 18 to get married.
translation.yo: Lọ́dún-un 2016, Gyumi na ọwọ́ ìka àbùkù sí agbára Òfin Ìgbéyàwó; Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) tí ó gba obìnrin tí kò tó ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún láyè láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó.

translation.en: According to Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS),  36 percent of women aged 25-49 get married before their 18th birthday compared to only 5 percent for men the same age.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí nípa ìlera Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS) ṣe ti ṣàlàyé, ìdá 36 obìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n wà ní 25-49 ní í ṣe ìgbéyàwó kí wọn ó tó pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún, tí àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn lọ́kùnrin sí jẹ́ ìdá 5.

translation.en: The LMA allowed girls as young as 14 to get married with consent from a court and age 15 with the consent of the parents whereas 18 years was the minimum age for a male.
translation.yo: Òfin LMA fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọn kò ju ọdún mẹ́rìnlá lọ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó pẹ̀lú ìlọ́wọ́sí ilé-ẹjọ́, ìlọ́wọ́sí òbí fún ọmọ ọdún márùn-ún-dínlógún, nígbà tí ọdún méjìdínlógún jẹ́ ọjọ́ orí tí ó kéré jù lọ fún ọmọkùnrin.

translation.en: Through her attorneys, Gyumi argued that the LMA provisions were discriminatory for giving preferential treatment to males in the matter of eligible marriage age.
translation.yo: Nípasẹ̀ àwọn aṣojú rẹ̀, Gyumi ṣàlàyé wípé àlàálẹ̀ LMA kọ iyán obìnrin kéré nítorí pé ó fún àwọn ọkùnrin ní àǹfààní ju àwọn obìnrin lọ.

translation.en: They further argued that the provisions infringed the right to equality and they were too vague and too susceptible to arbitrary interpretation to deny female children their right to education.
translation.yo: Nítẹ̀síwájú, wọ́n sọ wípé àlàálẹ̀ náà fi ẹ̀tọ́ dídọ́gba ọmọ ènìyàn yí ẹrẹ̀fọ̀ àti pé wọn fi ẹ̀tọ́ àǹfààní sí ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé dun àwọn ọmọdébìnrin.

translation.en: Gyumi petitioned the High Court to find the provisions of LMA null and void.
translation.yo: Gyumi rọ Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga láti gbé àlàálẹ̀ LMA tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.

translation.en: The High Court never declared the provisions in the LMA null and void.
translation.yo: Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga kò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

translation.en: But they found the provisions unconstitutional and gave the government one year to correct the anomalies in the LMA provisions.
translation.yo: Àmọ́ wọ́n rí i lóòótọ́ wípé kò bá òfin mu wọ́n sì fún ìjọba lọ́dún kan láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí ohun tí kò tọ̀nà nínú àlàálẹ̀ LMA.

translation.en: Through the attorney general, the government was directed to put 18 years as the eligible age of marriage for both females and males.
translation.yo: Nípasẹ̀ aṣojú àgbà àwọn adájọ́, a pa ìjọba láṣẹ láti gbé ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó sí ọdún méjìdínlógún fún obìnrin àti ọkùnrin.

translation.en: However, then-Attorney General George Masaju was aggrieved by the ruling and immediately served a notice of appeal to the High Court:
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, aṣojú àgbà àná banújẹ́ sí ìdájọ́ náà ó sì kọ ìwé àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ sí Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga náà:

translation.en: Official: I've been served government documents of appeal in the case of #childmarriage. Case number 204 of September 2017.
translation.yo: Pẹ̀lú ìfọwọ́sí àṣẹ ìjọba: mo ti gba ìwé àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ lóríi ẹjọ́ #childmarriage. Ẹjọ́ òǹkaye 204 ti oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ ọdún-un 2017.

translation.en: Read more: Mozambique criminalizes child marriage
translation.yo: Kà síwájú sí i: Mozambique sọ ìsoyìgì ọmọdé di ìwà ọ̀daràn

translation.en: Grounds for appeal
translation.yo: Àyè fún àtúnpè-ẹjọ́

translation.en: In four months of court proceedings, the government sought to appeal the 2016 ruling that required the revision of the provisions LMA that allowed girls to be married at the age of 15.
translation.yo: Láàárín oṣù mẹ́rin ìgbẹ́jọ́, ìjọba gbèrò láti ṣe àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí yó ṣe àtúnṣe sí àlàálẹ̀ LMA èyí tí ó fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin ọlọ́jọ́-orí márùn-úndínlógún gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹni tí ó ti bàlágà fún ìgbéyàwó.

translation.en: The appellant, represented by principal state attorneys, Mark Mulwambo and Alesia Mbuya, provided biological differences and customary and Islamic laws as grounds for the appeal.
translation.yo: Atẹ́jọ́pè, tí ó jẹ́ aṣojú àwọn adájọ́ ìpínlẹ̀, Mark Mulwambo àti Alesia Mbuya, ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá obìnrin àti ọkùnrin tí wọ́n sì fi àṣà ìbílẹ̀ àti òfin ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle gbá àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ náà nídìí.

translation.en: Ms. Mbuya argued that biological differences put boys and girls in "different categories" and that therefore, the law treats them differently.
translation.yo: Ms. Mbuya sọ wípé ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá fi ọmọdékùnrin àti ọmọdébìnrin sí "ìsọ̀rí ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ " àti pé, òfin fi ojú ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ wò wọ́n.

translation.en: She argued that because girls matured earlier, the law took that into consideration. She argued that marriage could protect unmarried girls who get pregnant at an early age.
translation.yo: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé nítorí àwọn ọmọdébìnrin máa ń tètè bàlágà ju ọmọdékùnrin lọ ni òfin fi la àlàálẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀. Ó sọ wípé ìgbéyàwó lè fi ààbò bo ọmọdébìnrin tí kò sí nílé ọkọ tí ó ti di abaraméjì láì tó ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́.

translation.en: Further, she argued the court erred by “equating the age of the child and the age of marriage,” meaning that the court should consider male and female children differently when it comes to marriageable age.
translation.yo: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé ilé ẹjọ́ kùnà bí ó ṣe “ṣe ìmúdọ́gbandọ́gba ọjọ́ orí ọmọ àti ọjọ́ orí tí ó yẹ fún ìgbéyàwó”, èyí tí ó túmọ̀ sí wípé ọ̀tọ̀ ni ti tọ́lú ọ̀tọ̀ ni ti tọ́lùú wò, ọ̀tọ̀ ni ó yẹ kí ilé ẹjọ́ ó là kalẹ̀ fún ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó ọkùnrin àti obìnrin.

translation.en: Netizens were quick to criticize the grounds the appellant provided in court.
translation.yo: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára ti yára bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ìdí tí àtẹ́jọ́pè fi sílẹ̀ nínú ìgbẹ́jọ́.

translation.en: Read more: Mozambique, Cote d'Ivoire make legal strides for women and children’s rights
translation.yo: Kà síwájú sí i: Mozambique, Cote d'Ivoire gbé ìgbésẹ̀ akọni fún ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn obìnrin àti ọmọdé

translation.en: Gender equality
translation.yo: Dídọ̀gba abo atakọ

translation.en: The court’s ruling is a step toward eliminating harmful practices and ending all forms of discrimination against girls in Tanzania.
translation.yo: Ìdájọ́ ilé ẹjọ́ náà jẹ́ atọ́ka sí ìfòpinsí àwọn àṣà tí ó ń mú ìpalára bá àwọn ọmọdébìnrin àti onírúurú ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà tòun ìfọwọ́rọ́sẹ́yìn àwọn ọmọdébìnrin ní Tanzania.

translation.en: According to the United Nations, in order to achieve gender equality by 2030, governments need to change discriminatory laws and adopt legislation that proactively advances equality.
translation.yo: Ní ti àjọ United Nations, kí a tó lè yege níbi ti dídọ́gba abo atakọ ní ọdún-un 2030, ìjọba ní láti ṣe àyípadà òfin ìyàsọ́tọ̀ọtọ̀ àti ṣíṣe àmúlò ìṣòfin tí yóò mú ìmúdọ́gba tí à ń sọ wáyé.

translation.en: Data shows that the age of marriage is directly related to levels of education and wealth (TDHS 201).
translation.yo: Àbájáde ìwádìí ṣe àfihàn-an rẹ̀ wípé ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó bá ìpele ìwé tí ènìyàn kà àti ọrọ̀ tí ènìyán ti kó jọ (TDHS 201) tan.

translation.en: In Tanzania, there is a 6-year difference between the age of marriage between girls with no education and girls with secondary or higher education.
translation.yo: Ní Tanzania, ó ní ìyàtọ̀ ọdún mẹ́fà tí ó wà láàárín ọmọdébìnrin tí kò lọ sí ilé ìwé àti àwọn tí ó ka ìwé gíga tàbí ìwé gíga jù lọ.

translation.en: In Tanzania, it is illegal to impregnate or marry schoolgirls with 30-year imprisonment as punishment.
translation.yo: Ní Tanzania, ohun tí kò bá òfin mu ni kí a fẹ́ tàbí fún akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin lóyún, ẹ̀wọ̀n ọgbọ̀n ọdún ni ẹní bá tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sófin yóò fi gbára.

translation.en: Pregnant schoolgirls are not allowed to return to school even after they have given birth.
translation.yo: Akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin tí ó bá lóyún kì í padà sí ilé ìwé pàápàá tí ó bá bímọ tán.

translation.en: The ban on child marriage will protect all girls, regardless of their school enrollment status.
translation.yo: Ìfòfinde ìsoyìgì pẹ̀lú ọmọdé máa ń fi ààbò fún àwọn ọmọdébìnrin, láì ro bí wọ́n ṣe wọ ilé ìwé.

translation.en: In Tanzania, child marriage bars girls from education and leads to school dropout, according to data from the Tanzania National Survey, 2017).
translation.yo: Ní Tanzania, ìgbéyàwó ọmọdébìnrin kì í jẹ kí ọmọdébìnrin ó kàwé tí wọn kò sì ní àǹfààní láti parí ẹ̀kọ́ọ wọn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí èsì ìwádìí láti Tanzania National Survey, 2017 ṣe ní i lákọsílẹ̀.

translation.en: This ban creates better conditions for schoolgirls to finish school without barriers.
translation.yo: Ìfòfinde ìsoyìgì yìí ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìgbé ayé tó dára fún akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin láti parí ẹ̀kọ́ọ wọn láì sí ìdádúró.

translation.en: Even so, impregnated schoolgirls are still faced with an unconstitutional ruling that prohibits them from returning to school.
translation.yo: Pẹ̀lú bẹ́ẹ̀, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin tí ó bá fẹ́rakù ṣì ń kojú òfin tí ó ní wọn kò gbọdọ̀ padà wá sílé ìwé.

translation.en: Kanye West's use of Jamaican symbols sparks national dialogue on ‘branding’
translation.yo: Ààmì ìdánimọ̀ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica tí Kanye West lò di awuyewuye tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lórí ‘ìsààmì’

translation.en: Jamaica-themed merchandise appeared in the online store
translation.yo: Ẹrù ọjà pẹ̀lú àkórí nípa Jamaica di títà lórí ayélujára

translation.en: Kanye West performs at The Museum of Modern Art's annual Party in the Garden benefit, New York City, May 10, 2011. Photo by Jason Persse, CC BY-SA 2.0.
translation.yo: Kanye West ń kọrin níbi ayẹyẹ ọlọ́dọọdún Ilé-ọnà ti Ọnà Ìgbàlódé ní Garden benefit, New York City, ọjọ́ 10, oṣù karùn-ún, 2011. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Jason Persse, CC BY-SA 2.0.

translation.en: American rapper Kanye West brought his "Sunday Service" pop-up concert to Kingston, Jamaica, at the start of its National Heroes Day holiday weekend (October 19-21, 2019).
translation.yo: Ọ̀kọrin tàkasúfèé tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Kanye West gbé àríyá "Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀ " pop-up concert wá sí Kingston, Jamaica, ní kété tí ìsinmi ọjọ́ ọ̀sẹ̀ fún Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà (19-21, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019) yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀.

translation.en: This was the first time the rapper had taken his huge gospel choir outside the United States, reportedly at the request of a Jamaican member of his staff.
translation.yo: Èyí ni ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí ọ̀kọrin náà yóò kó ẹgbẹ́ akọrin ìyìnrere rẹ̀ kúrò ní Amẹ́ríkà, ní ìjẹ́pèe ti agbè fún ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe kan tí ó Ja kí ó gbé ètò náà wá sílùú òun.

translation.en: However, the event was besieged with criticism from the outset, culminating with West's unapproved use of Jamaican emblems on merchandise being sold on his website.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, àríyá náà tí rí ìtakò láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, tí ó Ho forí sọlẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àmì ìdánimọ̀ọ orílè-èdèe Jamaica tí West we lórí ọjà tí ó ń tà lóríi ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyée rẹ̀ láì gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.

translation.en: With just two days’ notice, the free concert took place at Emancipation Park in Kingston, the capital city — a location that jarred some commentators because of controversial comments West had made about slavery during a media interview in May 2018.
translation.yo: Láàárín ọjọ́ méjì ni ìkéde fi lọ síta, inúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tó wà ní Kingston, olú ìlú orílẹ̀ èdè náà ni bẹbẹ́ ti wáyé — ojú ibi tí ó mú àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ kan wí tẹnu wọn látàrí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tó mú àríyànjiyàn dání tí West sọ nípa òwò ẹrú nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò kan báyìí lóṣù karùn-ún ọdún-un 2018.

translation.en: The park was opened in 2002 in honour of the "full freedom" of 300,000 slaves in Jamaica on August 1, 1838.
translation.yo: Ọdún-un 2002 ni gbàgede náà di lílò ní ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún "òmìnira dójú àmì" fún àwọn ẹrú 300,000 ní Jamaica lọ́jọ́ 1, oṣù kẹjọ ọdún-un 1838.

translation.en: That may have been the first bone of contention around the concert, but it was not the last.
translation.yo: Ó lè jẹ́ èyí gan-an ni oun àkọ́kọ́ nípa àríyá orin náà, ṣùgbọ́n òun kọ́ ni ó gbẹ̀yìn.

translation.en: Even as Culture Minister Olivia "Babsy" Grange responded to early criticism by saying the country was benefitting from the concert, one music promoter felt the show, which was livestreamed on the Sunday Service website, "upstaged" other cultural activities over Heroes Day weekend.
translation.yo: Pàápàá jù lọ bí Olóòtú Ètò Àṣà Olivia "Babsy" Grange ṣe bẹnu-àtẹ́ lu àwọn alátakò nígbà tí ó sọ wípé orílẹ̀ èdè náà ṣe àbápín nínú èrè àríyá náà, ní èyí tí aṣagbátẹrù orin kan lérò wípé àríyá náà tí ó ṣe é wò lójú ẹsẹ̀ bí ó ṣe ń lọ lóríi ìtakùn àgbáyée Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀, "gba" àwọn ètò tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ àṣà ìbílẹ̀ tí ó jẹ́ ti Ìsinmi àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.

translation.en: In addition, Kingston residents, who suffered unusually heavy traffic flows throughout the week, predicted chaos and confusion during the evening rush hour.
translation.yo: Láfikún, àwọn olùgbée Kingston, tí ó bá súnkẹrẹ fàkẹrẹ kòdìmú lọ́sẹ̀ yẹn, fọ àfọ̀tẹ́lẹ̀ làásìgbò àti rọ̀tìrọti bí àwọn tó ṣíwọ́ iṣẹ́ bá ń darí lọ sílé nírọ̀lẹ́.

translation.en: Nevertheless, the concert went smoothly, several thousand Jamaicans  enjoyed the show and Jamaican media companies earned online kudos for their flawless production:
translation.yo: Láì sí àní-àní, àríyá náà lọ ní ìrọwọ́-ìrọsẹ̀, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn Nev orílẹ̀-èdèe Jamaica gbádùn-un àríyá náà tí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica náà gba ìgbóríyìn fún iṣẹ́ takuntakun tí wọ́n ṣe:

translation.en: Word on the street is that there may be a move by [Sunday Service] to seek patent/ownership rights on the Kingston, Jamaica logos as well as the fabled streamer-tailed humming bird.
translation.yo: Ìròyìn etíìgbọ́ ìgboro ni wípé ó ṣeé ṣe kí ìgbésẹ̀ wà láti (Ìsìn Ọjọ́-àìkú) láti gba àsẹ èmi-ni-monií/ẹ̀tọ́ oníhun ààmì ìdánimọ̀ọ Kingston, orílẹ̀ èdè Jamaica àti ti ẹyẹ olùlànà onírù gígùn.

translation.en: I have done a fair amount of online searches for information to corroborate the claim without luck but have come across their online release of merchandise bearing these landmark symbols, which coincided with the concert...
translation.yo: Mo ti ṣe àwọn ìwádìí kan lórí ayélujára tí mo sì ṣe àwárí láti fi ti ẹ̀rí lẹ́yìn àmọ́ kádàrá kò ṣe mí lóore, mo ṣalábàápàdé ọjàa wọn tí wọ́n ń tà lórí ayélujára tó ní àwọn ààmi ìdánimọ̀ wọ̀nyí, tí ó sì ṣe dọ́gba-n-dọ́gba pẹ̀lú àríyá náà...

translation.en: Jamaica’s reality is that successive political administrations have never fully appreciated the economic value of the brand "Jamaica" nor the symbols that [represent] that brand including its flag and its coat of arms.
translation.yo: Òtítọ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica ni wípé àwọn ìjọba àná kò fi ìgbàkan kọbiara sí ìgbéró èto ọrọ̀ Ajée ‘Jamaica’ tàbí àwọn ààmi ìdánimọ̀ tó jẹ́ ti wọn bíi àsíá àti àsíá apata.

translation.en: The same is true for our music and its associated brand marks, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae among others.
translation.yo: Bákannáà ni ó rí fún orin wa àti ohun tí ó rọ̀ mọ́, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

translation.en: That Jamaica was blindsided by the release of clothing bearing the island’s important symbols is a classic case of guerilla marketing.
translation.yo: Ilẹ̀ Jamaica kò tètè lajú sí òwò aṣọ ṣíṣe tí ó ní ààmì pàtàkì erékùṣù tí yóò mú àwọn ènìyàn rà á wìtìwìtì.

translation.en: Having a concert to promote the line at the historic Emancipation Park provides tacit assent of not only the line of garments by the government and people of Jamaica, but also of the use of the country’s national symbols in their creation.
translation.yo: Bí a bá fi ètò àríyá ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àwọn ọjà wọ̀nyí nínúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tí ó mú ìlọsíwájú bá ohun tí ó ju aṣọ lọ láti ọ̀dọ̀ ìjọba àti àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica náà, pẹ̀lú lílo àwọn ààmìi orílẹ̀ èdè náà ní ọ̀nà àrà.

translation.en: I have noticed that there is now hurried pushback by the Ministry of Culture as well as from the Mayor of Kingston. Both should realize that this isn’t a bottle that will be easy to re-cork.
translation.yo: Mo ti ṣe àkíyèsí wípé Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Àṣà àti Olùdarí ìlúu Kingston ti ń gbé ìgbésẹ̀ẹ pàjáwìrì láti ra nǹkan padà. Kí àwọn méjèèjì mọ̀ pé àtúnṣe kì í ṣe nǹkan tó ma yá kíákíá.

translation.en: I hope that the government has good lawyers.
translation.yo: Mo lérò wípé ìjọba ní àwọn agbẹjọ́rò tó ká ojú òṣùwọ̀n.

translation.en: Indeed, lawyers may still have quite a bit of work to do to untangle the confusion surrounding the use of Jamaica's national symbols.
translation.yo: Lóòótọ́, àwọn agbẹjọ́rò ṣì níṣẹ́ láti ṣe láti tú kókó awuyewuye etí aṣọ ti lílo àsíá orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica.

translation.en: Deadly police raids in Guinea as President Alpha Condé clings to power
translation.yo: Ìrọ́lù ọlọ́pàá tí í mú ikú bá ‘ni ní Guinea bí Ààrẹ Alpha Condé ṣe kọ̀ láì gbé’ jọba sílẹ̀

translation.en: "Cities have been paralyzed"
translation.yo: "Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú ti kọ̀yìn síjọba lórí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí"

translation.en: Screenshot from a France 24 news flash about the situation in Guinea.
translation.yo: Àgékù ohun tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Guinea láti ìròyìn ránpẹ́ France 24 kan.

translation.en: Police violence erupted in Guinea on October 14, resulting in the death of several people and massive arrests, following demonstrations protesting against current president Alpha Condé's plans to modify the constitution to run for a third term.
translation.yo: Ìwà ipá bẹ́ sílẹ̀ ní Guinea lọ́jọ́ 14 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, tí ó ti fa ikú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí wọ́n sì ń kó àwọn ènìyàn kiri lẹ́yìn ìyíde ìféhónúhàn tí ó tako ìjọba ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí oyè ìyẹn Alpha Condé, ẹni tí ó ń gbèrò láti yí ìwé-òfin padà kí ó bá fi ààyè gba òun láti lọ fún ìgbà kẹta.

translation.en: The streets of the capital, Conakry, and other cities have turned into battlefields between law enforcement forces and demonstrators.
translation.yo: Ojúu pópó olú ìlú náà, Conakry, àti àwọn ìlú tó kù ti di ojú ogun láàárín àjọ agbófinró àti àwọn ọmọ ìlú tó ń fi èhónú hàn.

translation.en: Police forces have the advantage of new legal privileges that allow them to use deadly force if they deem it necessary for security reasons.
translation.yo: Iléeṣẹ́ ọlọ́pàá ti lo àǹfààní tuntun tí ó fún wọn láṣẹ láti lo ohun ìjà aṣekúpani bí ó bá dé ojú ẹ̀.

translation.en: The demonstrations have already killed six people, including one police officer, and wounded many.
translation.yo: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti rán ẹni mẹ́fà sí ọ̀run àjànto, ní èyí tí ó jẹ́ pé ọlọ́pàá kan wà nínúu àwọn tí ó jẹ́ Ògún nípè, ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ló sì fi ara pa.

translation.en: Read more: Security forces in Guinea now have the right to use deadly force
translation.yo: Kà síwájú sí i: Àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò ní Guinea ti ní àṣẹ láti lo ohun ìjà aṣekúpani

translation.en: Demonstrators oppose any change to the constitution seen as an attempt by the president to run legally for a third mandate.
translation.yo: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn kò lọ́wọ́ sí kílàńkó àyípadà sí ìwé-òfin tí wọ́n rí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìgbésẹ̀ ààrẹ láti wà lórí ipò fún ẹlẹ́ẹ̀kẹ́ta.

translation.en: Indeed, the constitution limits the total number of presidential mandates to two in a row. Condé, now 81, should end his mandate in October 2020.
translation.yo: Ní tòótọ́, ìwé-òfin náà fi ààyè ọdún méjì gba ẹni tí ó bá wà ní ipò ààrẹ láti ṣèjọba. Condé, ẹni ọdún 81, yẹ kí sáà rẹ̀ ó parí ní oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2020.

translation.en: Demonstrators are particularly vulnerable as they operate in violation of the law, as Human Rights Watch reminds:
translation.yo: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ni a lè ṣá lọ́gbẹ́ jù lọ nítorí wípé wọ́n tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin náà bí Human Rights Watch ṣe pè fún àkíyèsí:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: The government of Guinea has effectively banned street protests for more than a year, citing threats to public security, Human Rights Watch said today.
translation.yo: Human Rights Watch sọ lónìí wípé, ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdèe Guinea ti gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ìfèhònúhàn l'ójúu pópó fún ọdún kan, ó tọ́ka sí ìdojú-ìjà-kọ ààbò ìlú.

translation.en: Local authorities have prohibited at least 20 political or other demonstrations.
translation.yo: Àwọn aláṣẹ ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ ti fọ́n ó tó bíi ogún ìfèhònúhàn ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú àti àwọn mìíràn ká yángá.

translation.en: Security forces have tear gassed those who defy the ban, and arrested dozens of demonstrators.
translation.yo: Àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò ti sọ tajútajú sí àárín àwọn tí kò gbọ́ràn láti tú wọn ká, wọ́n sì kó àìmọye ènìyàn.

translation.en: Regarding the political situation, the government is delivering conflicting messages: On October 13, President Condé welcomed a dialogue:
translation.yo: Ní ti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ òṣèlú náà, àjọ ọba náà ń kéde iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ tí ó ń tako ara wọn: Ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà Ààrẹ Condé fẹ́ ìsọ̀rọ̀-ní-tùnbí-ǹ-nùbí:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: Alpha Condé has reiterated his call for a responsible dialogue and for a permanent process of discussions in order to iron out differences and answer all the challenges the country is facing.
translation.yo: Alpha Condé ti pè fún ìsọ̀rọ̀ ní tùnbíǹnùbí ó sì fẹ́ kí ìjókòó gẹ́gẹ́ bí tọmọtìyá tí yóò fi pẹ̀lẹ́pùtù yanjú gbọ́nmi-síi-omi-ò-tóo tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ àti ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí àwọn ìpèníjà tí ó ń kojú orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

translation.en: Yet, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, a presidential counselor, stated the following day on October 12, —two days before the demonstrations started, — to a crowd of RPG youth [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea party]:
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, olùdámọ̀ràn ipò ààrẹ, sọ lọ́jọ́ tí ó tẹ̀lé e, ìyẹn ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, — ọjọ́ méjì kí ìfẹ̀hònúhàn ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, — fún àwọn èrò tó jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ langba RPG ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea]:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: We invite the party's youth to remain vigilant in the districts.
translation.yo: A rọ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú náà láti kún fún ìṣọ́ra ní ojúu pópó.

translation.en: They [the opposition activists] have stocked use tires in wholes, we invite young people from the party to get those tires out, prevent them from acting, get those hidden tires, do not attack anyone, do not destroy anything, just defend yourselves.
translation.yo: Àwọn [tí àwọn jẹ́ ajìjàngbara alátakò] ti fa ìṣòro, a pe àwọn ìpẹ́ẹ̀rẹ́ láti inú ẹgbẹ́ náà láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí ìṣòro tó wà nílẹ̀, àmọ́ kí ẹ máà dojú ìjà kọ ẹnikẹ́ni, kí ẹ máà ba dúkìá kankan jẹ́, ju ìdáàbò bo ara yín lọ.

translation.en: All evil-doers will be found and shown to the people.
translation.yo: Gbogbo àwọn oníṣẹ́-ibi ni ó di àwárí tí a ó fi ojúu wọn hàn f'áráyé rí.

translation.en: This double talk amongst those in power has further angered the opposition and civil society, according to the site globalguinee.info:
translation.yo: Ẹnu méjì àwọn tí ó ń tukọ̀ ìlú ti túbọ̀ mú inú bí ẹgbẹ́ alátakò àti àwọn àjàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn, ó ní bí ìtakùn globalguinee.info ṣe sọ:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: October 14, 2019, is a dark Monday, if not black, responding to the call made by the FNDC [National Front for the Defense of the Constitution], Guineans took massively to the streets to oppose the project of constitutional changes.
translation.yo: Ọjọ́ 14 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019 jẹ́ ọjọ́ Ajé burúkú Èṣù gbomi mu, ní ti ìfèsì sí ìpè àjọ FNDC [Àwọn tí ó ń lé wájú ń'nú Ìdáàbò bo Ìwé-òfin Orílẹ̀-èdè], àwọn ọmọ Guinea tú yáyá tú yàyà sí ojúu títì láti tako ìgbésẹ̀ àtúnṣe sí ìwé-òfin.

translation.en: Clashes were reported in different districts of the Guinean capital.
translation.yo: Ìkọlù wáyé ní àwọn agbègbè tí ó wà ní àárín olú ìlú orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

translation.en: Business in the administrative center of Kalou was almost entirely stopped.
translation.yo: Káràkátà dẹnu kọlẹ̀ ní àárín gbùngbùn ibi ìṣàkóso ìlú ní Kalou.

translation.en: Inside the country, people also responded to the call in Middle and Lower Guinea.
translation.yo: Àwọn tí ó wà ní Àárín àti Odò orílẹ̀ èdè Guinea náà gbọ́ ìpè, wọ́n sì darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn ọmọ ìlú tó kù.

translation.en: In the forest and in Higher Guinea, not so much.
translation.yo: Ènìyàn díẹ̀ ni ó jáde ní ìgbèríko àti Òkèe Guinea.

translation.en: Yet, cities have been paralyzed.
translation.yo: Àmọ́ ṣá, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú ti kọ̀yìn síjọba lórí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí.

translation.en: Expressing himself on benbere.org, a Malian platform for youth, Malian blogger Adam Thiam writes:
translation.yo: Ní oríi benbere.org, gbàgede ìtàkùrọ̀sọ fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ní Mali, akọ̀ròyin búlọ́ọ̀gù Adam Thiam kọ:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: Serious things are now happening in Guinea, with incendiary escalation, almost random dead demonstrators riddles with bullets, blood trails on pavements with barricades and crossroads smoking with tires in flames and tear gas.
translation.yo: Nǹkan kàyèéfì ń lọ lọ́wọ́ lọ́wọ́ báyìí ní Guinea, pẹ̀lú ìrógbàmù tí ó ń wáyé, ọta ìbon ti fọ́ sí ara àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn tí ó sì ti ṣekú pa ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ọ wọn, ẹ̀jẹ̀ ní ojúu pópó, ìdígàgá ní gbogbo, iná ẹsẹ̀ ọkọ̀ọ sísun àti tajútajú nínú afẹ́fẹ́.

translation.en: Netizens have denounced the violence on social media:
translation.yo: Àwọn ọmọ ìlú orí ayélujára fajúro sí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà lórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà:

translation.en: Just like Blaise Compaoré [Burkinabé politician] Alpha Condé is going straight to the abyss, Will he be able to hear the angry shouting of his compatriots?
translation.yo: Bíi ti Blaise Compaoré [olóṣèlúu Burkinabé] Alpha Condé ń forí lé ibi ìparun, ǹjẹ́ yó leè gbóhùn inúbíbí àwọn aráa rẹ̀ bí?

translation.en: The very near future will tell us. Meanwhile, the boat is sinking.
translation.yo: Ó di ọjọ́ iwájú kí á tó mọ̀. Ní báyìí ṣá, ọkọ̀ ojú omi ti ń ré.

translation.en: On October 15, Guinean journalist Bhiye Bary wrote:
translation.yo: Lọ́jọ́ 15 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, akọ̀ròyin Guinea Bhiye Bary kọ:

translation.en: Hamdallaye pharmacy (#Conakry): certain citizens woken up by the police forces early this morning.
translation.yo: Ilé ìtòògùn Hamdallaye (#Conakry): àwọn ọlọ́pàá ló jí àwọn ọmọ ìlú kan lójú oorun ní òwúrọ̀ yìí.

translation.en: According to a local citizen, the police forces are breaking down doors and looting houses.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹnìkan ti ṣe sọ, àwọn ọlọ́pàá ń jálẹ̀kùn tí wọ́n sì ń kó ẹrù nílé onílé.

translation.en: S. Nkola Matamba, a writer and human rights activist from the Democratic Republic of Congo, shared his bitterness:
translation.yo: S. Nkola Matamba, òǹkọ̀wé àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ Ìlú Olómìnira Ìjọba ara wa ti Congo, fi ìbánújẹ́ ọkàn hàn:

translation.en: A former member of the opposition, and now devoured by the desire to change the law to allow a third mandate, maybe to remain on the throne till the end, Alpha Condé embodies of of the dark sides of the kind of Africa that keeps taking us down!
translation.yo: Ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ alátakò ìgbàkan, tí ó wá fẹ́ yí òfin padà nítorí ìfẹ́ ara rẹ̀ kí ó ba ṣèjòba fún ìgbà kẹta, bóyá kí ó bá jẹ gàba títí tí Ọlọ́jọ́ yóò fi dé, Alpha Condé gan-an ni àpẹẹrẹ ibi tí ó ń fa ìfàsẹ́yìn fún Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ !

translation.en: People of Guinea, have courage!
translation.yo: Ẹ̀yin aráa Guinea, ẹ mú ọkàn le!

translation.en: #GUINÉE – It's simply appalling. First day of demonstration against a third mandate for Condé and here we are with an outcome of victims and dead people.
translation.yo: #GUINÉE – ó jẹ́ ohun ìyàlẹ́nu. Ìfẹ̀hònúhàn ìtako ìṣèjọba Condé fún ìgbà kẹta ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo tí mú ẹ̀mí àwọn ènìyàn lọ.

translation.en: This craziness of politicians who want to remain head of state for life  Amoulanfe— Cheikh Fall™ (@cypher007) October 14, 2019
translation.yo: Sísíwín àwọn olóṣèlú tí ó fẹ́ kú sórí ipò ààrẹ yìí ti ń pọ̀ jù Amoulanfe— Cheikh Fall™ (@cypher007) ọjọ́ 14, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019

translation.en: Guinean activist Macky Darsalam noted attempts made to manipulate public opinion:
translation.yo: Ajìjàǹgbara Guinea Macky Darsalam sọ ti ìgbésẹ̀ láti tọwọ́ bọ èròńgbà àwọn ará ìlú lójú:

translation.en: The Guinean opposition seems defenseless in the face of such attacks: the deputies of all opposition parties have stopped participating in parliamentary debates since October 11, 2019.
translation.yo: Ẹgbẹ́ alátakò Guinea náà kò ní ààbò tí ó lè fi bo araa rẹ̀ lásìkò ìkọlù: àwọn aṣojú aláṣẹ ẹgbẹ́ alátakò gbogbo kò dá sí àríyànjiyàn ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba mọ́ láti ọjọ́ 11, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019.

translation.en: Violence against these parties has taken on radical forms, as the site mediaguinee.org notes:
translation.yo: Ìwà ipá sí àwọn ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú wọ̀nyí ti gba ọ̀nà àrà, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ibùdó ìtakùn mediaguinee.org ṣe kọ:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: ...at the headquarter of the Union of Republican Forces (URF) of Sidya Touré district, clashes took place between certain members of the opposition and pro-government militants who had taken measures the day before to prevent any unauthorized demonstration in the stronghold of the ruling party.
translation.yo: ...ní olú iléeṣẹ́ Union of Republican Forces (URF) tí agbègbè Sidya Touré, ìjá wáyé láàárín àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ alátakò kan àti àwọn tí ó ń fẹ́ ti ìjọba tí ó ti ṣètò tí kò ní jẹ́ kí ìyíde ìfẹ̀hónúhàn náà ó wáyé lọ́jọ́ kan sí ọjọ́ ìfẹ̀hónúhàn ní àwọn agbègbè tí wọ́n ti lẹ́nu.

translation.en: The clashes ended with a ransacked office of the URF and the arrest of six people whose identity and party affiliation remain yet unknown to the public.
translation.yo: Ìkọlù náà wá sí òpin lẹ́yìn-in ìkólọ iléeṣẹ́ URF náà tí àwọn ènìyàn mẹ́fà tí kò sí ẹni tó mọ orúkọ àti ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú tí wọ́n ń bá ṣe di èrò àtìmọ́lé.

translation.en: #SexForGrades: A new documentary exposes sexual harassment at West African universities
translation.yo: #SexForGrades: Ètò Alálàyé-afẹ̀ríhàn tú àṣìírí ìwà ìyọlẹ́nu ìbálòpọ̀ ní àwọn Ifásitìi Ìwọ-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀

translation.en: Victims fear a backlash and are often unwilling to talk
translation.yo: Ìtìjú mú àwọn tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ṣẹlẹ̀ sí máà leè sọ

translation.en: This masked victim was repeatedly sexually abused by Boniface Igbeneghu, a professor in University of Lagos, Nigeria (Screenshot from BBC #SexForGrades video)
translation.yo: Boniface Igbeneghu, ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n Ifásitìi Èkó, Nàìjíríà ti bá ẹni tí ó wọ ìbòjú yìí ṣe erée gélé ní àìmọye ìgbà (Àwòrán láti BBC #SexForGrades)

translation.en: #SexForGrades, a BBC documentary on sexual harassment of female students by university professors in Nigeria and Ghana, has ignited heated online conversation and raises many questions about how to put an end to it:
translation.yo: #SexForGrades, ètò alálàyé afẹ̀ríhàn-an BBC kan tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lóríi àṣemáṣe eré ìfẹ́ tí àwọn ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n ifásitì pẹ̀lú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìrin ní Nàìjíríà àti Ghana ti ràn bíi pápá inú ọyẹ́ ní orí ayélujára tí ó sì ti fa àwọn ìbéèrè ọlọ́kanòjọ̀kan nípa ọ̀nà tí a leè gbà dẹ́kùn àṣemáṣe ọ̀hún láwùjọ:

translation.en: The groundbreaking investigation, released on October 7, 2019, was anchored by journalist Kiki Mordi, who was forced to abandon her own university degree because she refused to yield to the sexual advances by a university teacher who kept failing her:
translation.yo: Àgbà iṣẹ́ ìwádìí náà, tí ó di gbígbé jáde ní ọjọ́ kéje oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019, tí akọ̀ròyin Kiki Mordi tí kò parí ẹ̀kọ́ọ rẹ̀ látàríi wípé kò fẹ́ ṣe àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú olùkọ́ní ifásitì rẹ̀ tí ó ń fi ìdíi rẹ̀ rẹmi nínú ìdánwò nítorí wípé kò fún un ṣe ṣe atọ́kùn-un rẹ̀:

translation.en: Boniface Igbeneghu, University of Lagos, is caught sexually harassing female students in an undercover investigation by the BBC.
translation.yo: Boniface Igbeneghu, Ifásitì Èkó, tí a ká ìwà àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìrin nínú ìwádìí abẹ́lẹ̀ tí BBC ṣe.

translation.en: Screenshot from BBC #SexForGrades video.
translation.yo: Àwòrán láti BBC #SexForGrades.

translation.en: The nearly one-year investigation revealed the scandal of “sex for grades” crises at two West African universities: Nigeria's University of Lagos (UNILAG) and the University of Ghana.
translation.yo: Ìwádìí tí ó pé wákàtí kan tú àṣìírí ìwà àṣemáṣe ti “eré ìfẹ́ fún ojú-àmì ẹ̀kọ́” ní ifásitì Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ méjì: University of Lagos (UNILAG) ti Nàìjíríà àti University of Ghana.

translation.en: Nigeria's Boniface Igbeneghu, a professor in UNILAG'S faculty of art and an evangelical pastor of local Foursquare Gospel Church, Lagos, was one of the teachers busted by the investigation.
translation.yo: Boniface Igbeneghu, tí í ṣe kòfẹ́sọ̀ ní ẹ̀ka iṣẹ́ ọnà ti UNILAG, tí ó sì tún jẹ́ àlùfáà Ìjọ Foursquare Gospel, ní Èkó, ń bẹ nínú àwọn olùkọ́ tí òkété bórù mọ́ lọ́wọ́.

translation.en: Igbenegbu is seen in the BBC video sexually propositioning an undercover BBC reporter who pretended to be a 17-year-old seeking university admission. Igbenegu can be heard saying:
translation.yo: A rí Igbeneghu nínúu ètòo BBC náà tí ó kọ ẹnu ìfẹ́ sí ọmọdébìnrin tí ó díbọ́n gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọ ọlọ́jọ́ orí mẹ́tàdínlógún tí ó ń wà ìgbanisílé ẹ̀kọ́ láì fura wípé ajábọ̀ ìròyìn tí ó ń ṣe iṣẹ́ ìwádìí abẹ́lẹ̀ fún BBC ni ó ń ṣe. Igbeneghu sọ báyìí wípé:

translation.en: Don’t you know you are a beautiful girl?
translation.yo: Ṣé o kò mọ̀ wípé ọmọbìnrin arẹwà ni ọ́ ?

translation.en: Do you know I am a pastor and I am in my 50's but if I want a girl of 17 years, all I need is a sweet tongue and put some money...
translation.yo: Ǹjẹ́ o mọ̀ wípé àlùfáà ìjọ ẹlẹ́sìn ìgbàgbọ́ ni mo jẹ́, àti pé mo tó ẹni àádọ́ta ọdún ṣùgbọ́n bí mo bá fẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́tàdínlógún ọ̀rọ̀ dídùn àti owó ni ó máa jẹ...

translation.en: In a final meeting between the pair, Igbenegbu switched off the lights, asked her for a kiss and went ahead to hug her in his locked office.
translation.yo: Níbi ìpàdé kan láàárín àwọn méjèèjì, Igbeneghu ṣẹ́ iná pa, ó sì ní kí ọmọdébìnrin náà ó fẹ́nu ko òhun lẹ́nu, tí ó sì tún dì mọ́ ọn gbádígbádí nínúu iyàraa iṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ tí ó wà ní títì pa.

translation.en: Foursquare Gospel Church has suspended Igbeneghu "from all ministerial assignments".
translation.yo: Ìjọ Ajíhìnrere Foursquare ti dá Igbeneghu dúró "lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ ìhìn rere".

translation.en: Similarly, the University of Lagos has barred Igbeneghu from the school and also ordered the shutdown of the staff club’s "cold room", used by senior staff to hold parties attended by young female students and staff.
translation.yo: Bákan náà, Ifásitì Èkó ti lé Igbeneghu kúrò ní ilé ìwé wọ́n sì ti sún ìpèré sí ẹ̀hìn ilẹ̀kùn ilé òṣìṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń pè ní "yàrá tútù", tí àwọn ọ̀gá olùkọ́ni ti máa ń ṣe àríyá níbi tí wọ́n ti máa ń gba àwọn ọ̀ṣọ́rọ̀ ọmọge lálejò.

translation.en: Recounting the trauma of years past
translation.yo: Àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìbànújẹ́ ọdún sẹ́yìn

translation.en: This exposé ignited reactions of cataclysmic proportions from Nigerians online with the trending hashtag #SexForGrades on Twitter.
translation.yo: Àkàrà tí ó tú sépo yìí ti fi gọ̀ngọ̀ fa kòmóòkùn ọ̀rọ̀ jáde lẹ́nu ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ní orí ayélujára pẹ̀lú àmìi #SexForGrades ní oríi Twitter.

translation.en: Many female Twitter users recount their own experiences of sexual harassment:
translation.yo: Púpọ̀ nínú àwọn òǹlò tí ó jẹ́ abo ní oríi Twitter fi ẹ̀dùn ọkàn-an wọn hàn nípa ìríríi wọn lóríi ìwà erée gélé ti ìbálòpọ̀:

translation.en: Lola Shoneyin, book festival curator and author, recounted the "terrible shame" she felt after she was touched inappropriately by a university Deputy Vice-Chancellor (DVC):
translation.yo: Lọlá Ṣónẹ́yìn, alátinúdáa àjọ̀dún ìwé àti òǹkọ̀wé, ṣàlàyé "ìtìjú ńlá" tí òhún rí nígbà tí amúgbálẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ ọ̀gá pátápátá ifásitì kan (DVC) fọwọ́ kan ibi tí kò yẹ kí ó fọwọ́ kàn lára òun:

translation.en: Philandering university professors have for decades debased female students in Nigerian tertiary institutions.
translation.yo: Àwọn ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n oníṣìná ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga Nàìjíríà ti ba ti àwọn obìnrin jẹ́.

translation.en: However, it is usually difficult to prosecute perpetrators because victims are afraid of the backlash and unwilling to talk due to deep trauma associated with these abuses.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, nítorí ìtìjú àwọn tí ó fi ara pa kì í leè sọ̀rọ̀ síta èyí kò sì jẹ́ kí ó rọrùn láti dá sẹ̀ríà fún àwọn awùwà ìbàjẹ́.

translation.en: In 2016, the "Sexual Harassment in Tertiary Education Institution Prohibition Bill", passed by the Nigerian Senate prescribed a 5-year jail term for lecturers and educators convicted of sexually harassing students.
translation.yo: Ní ọdún-un 2016, Ìgbìmọ̀ Àṣòfin mú àbá ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún márùn-ún wá fún olùkọ́ní tí ilé ẹjọ́ bá dá lẹ́bi àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nínú "Ìwé àbádòfin Ìfòpin sí ìwà ìbàjẹ́ ìbálòpọ̀ ní Ilé Ìwé Gíga".

translation.en: However, the Academic Staff Union of Nigerian Universities opposed the bill, claiming that it was discriminatory since it targeted teachers and that it undermined university autonomy.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, Àjọ Olùkọ́ni Ifásitìi Nàìjíríà kọ ẹ̀yìn sí ìwé àbá yìí, wọ́n ní ó kọ iyán àwọn kéré, nítorí ó kọjú ìjà sí àwọn olùkọ́ àti wípé ó yẹpẹrẹ àṣẹ àti agbára ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga.

translation.en: The opposition to the bill may have led to the death of that legislation — which did not get presidential assent.
translation.yo: Ìsọtasí ìwé àbá náà pa òfin náà ní àpakú finínfinfín — èyí kò sì jẹ́ kí ààrẹ ó bu ọwọ́ lù ú.

translation.en: Is #SexForGrades another #ChurchToo movement?
translation.yo: Ṣé Eré ìfẹ́ fún ojú-àmì Ẹ̀kọ́ #SexForGrades ni ìjìjàngbara ilé ìjọsìn #ChurchToo tuntun?

translation.en: In July this year, Nigeria's celebrity photographer, Busola Dakolo, accused Biodun Fatoyinbo, the lead pastor of Commonwealth of Zion Assembly (COZA), of forcefully raping her when she was 16.
translation.yo: Nínú oṣù kéje ọdún yìí, gbajúgbajà ayàwòrán-an nì, Bùsọ́lá Dakolo, fi ẹ̀sùn kan Bíọ́dún Fátóyìnbó, àlùfáà àgbà ìjọ Commonwealth of Zion Assembly (COZA), wípé ó fi ipá bá òun ní àjọṣepọ̀ nígbà tí òhún wà ní ọmọ ọdún mẹ́rindínlógún.

translation.en: Read more: Pastor or predator?
translation.yo: Kà síwájú sí i: Àlùfáà tàbí apanijẹ bí ẹ̀pa?

translation.en: Nigerian Evangelical preacher embroiled in rape accusations
translation.yo: Ajíhìnrere Oníwàásù nínúu wàhálà ẹ̀sùn ìfipábánilòpọ̀

translation.en: Over the past six years, the flamboyant Fatoyinbo has been plagued by allegations of rape and sexual abuse.
translation.yo: Fún ọdún mẹ́fà tí ó ré kọjá lọ, Fátóyìnbó aródẹ́dẹ́ ti rí ìfẹ̀sùnkàn ìfipábánilòpọ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan.

translation.en: However, the emotional interview during which Dakolo accused Fatoyinbo ignited a national reaction online.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò tí Dakolo ti fẹ̀sùn kan Fátóyìnbó dá awuyewuye sílẹ̀ lórí ayélukára bí ajere.

translation.en: For days, #ChurchToo — a national iteration of the global #MeToo movement — trended on social media in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Fún ọjọ́ díẹ̀, ilé ìjọsìn náà; #ChurchToo — tí í ṣe àpẹẹrẹ èmi náà ní àgbáyé #MeToo — gba ayélujára kan ní Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: This agitation soon morphed from online to street protests in major Nigerian cities like Lagos and Abuja.
translation.yo: Ẹ̀sùn yìí fò fẹ̀rẹ̀ láti orí ayélujára sí ìfẹ̀hónúhàn lóríi òpópónà ní àwọn ìlú ńlá ní Nàìjíríà bíi Èkó àti Abuja.

translation.en: The #ChurchToo movement called on the government to take "the issue of violence against women and girls seriously".
translation.yo: Ìpèsí àkíyèsí ilé ìjọsìn náà #ChurchToo movement rọ ìjọba láti da “ọ̀ràn-an ìjìyà obìnrin àti ọmọdébìnrin dúrò.”

translation.en: The #ChurchToo revealed the silent but "horrific thriving rape culture, especially within religious circles" in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Ilé ìjọsìn náà #ChurchToo ṣípayá ìdákẹ́ rọ́rọ́ àmọ́ "ìbàjẹ́ àṣà ìfipábánilòpọ̀ tí ó ń gbèrú, pàápàá jù lọ ní agbo ìjọsìn" ní Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: It provided an opportunity for women to speak out.
translation.yo: Ó fún àwọn obìnrin ní àǹfààní láti wí ti ẹnu wọn.

translation.en: Like the #ChurchToo movement, the #SexForGrades outcry has again revealed the realities of sexual violence against women and the abuse of power that allows this sexual violence to thrive.
translation.yo: Bíi ti #ChurchToo, ìké tantan eré ìfẹ́ fún ojú-àmì ẹ̀kọ́ #SexForGrades ti fẹ ìdí ìlòkulò agbára tí ó bí ìwà àṣemáṣe ti ìbánilájọ̀ṣepọ̀ tí àwọn obìnrin kò fi tọkàntọkàn fẹ́ síta gbangba.

translation.en: Will this hashtag lead to an offline advocacy movement that pushes for reforms to ensure that universities are safe places for women?
translation.yo: Ǹjẹ́ àmì orí ayélujára yìí yóò ṣe amọ̀nàa ìgbèjà ẹ̀tọ́ tí kì í ṣe ti orí ayélujára tí yóò béèrè fún àtúnṣe tí yóò sọ ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga ifásitì di ibi ààbò fún àwọn obìnrin bí?

translation.en: Time will tell.
translation.yo: Ìgbà àti àkókò nìkan ni yóò sọ.

translation.en: Zanzibar's one and only music academy on the brink of closure
translation.yo: Ilé ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀ orin kíkọ kan ṣoṣo ní Zanzibar ti fẹ́ di títì pa

translation.en: Dhow Countries Music Academy promotes Swahili culture through music
translation.yo: Ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ Orin Kíkọ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-èdè Dhow f'orin ṣègbélárugẹ àṣàa Swahili

translation.en: Students from the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA) rehearse the qanun, flute, drum and piano at the Old Customs House, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
translation.yo: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ láti Iléèwé Orin kíkọ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-èdèe Dhow (DCMA) ń fi qanun, fèrè, ìlù àti dùrù ní Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́, ní Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA ló ni àwòrán.

translation.en: Thousands of visitors to the historic city of Stone Town, Zanzibar, have followed the sound of music to the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that promotes and preserves the islands’ musical traditions of the Swahili Coast along the Indian Ocean.
translation.yo: Ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àlejò tí ó ń rọ́ wìtìwìtì wá sí ìlú Stone Town, Zanzibar tí ó kún fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá, ti tẹ̀lé ìró orin Iléèwé Orin kíkọ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-èdèe Dhow (DCMA), ilé ẹ̀kọ́ orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àwọn àṣà orin erékùṣù náà tí ó sún mọ́ Swahili ní ẹ̀báa Omi Òkun India.

translation.en: Since 2002, the school has promoted and preserved the Zanzibar's unique mix of Arab, Indian and African cultures through music.
translation.yo: Láti ọdún-un 2002, ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà ti ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àkójọpọ̀ orin Lárúbáwá, India àti Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí kò lẹ́lẹ́gbẹ́.

translation.en: After 17 years, the school faces a financial crisis that threatens its closure.
translation.yo: Lẹ́yìn-in ọdún kẹtàdínlógún, iléèwé náà kò rí owó tí ó tówó nínú àpò ìkówó sí tí ó sì leè fa kí iléèwé náà ó di títì pa.

translation.en: Nearly 70% of its 80 full-time students can't afford to pay their tuition, which comes to about $13 USD per month, according to an official DCMA press release.
translation.yo: Nínú ìwé ìgbéròyìnjáde tí àwọn aláṣẹ DCMA tẹ̀ jáde, ìdá àádọ́rin nínú àwọn ọgọ́rin akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni kò rí owó iléèwé wọn tí ó tó bíi $13 USD lóṣù san.

translation.en: While the school has received support over the years from international donors and diplomatic missions, they face a gap in funding that may force them to shut their doors at the historic Old Customs House.
translation.yo: Pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn àwọn onínúure tí ó ti dáwó fún iléèwé náà, owó tí ó kù ní sísan ṣì pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó fi jẹ́ wípé, ó ṣe é ṣe kí ilẹ̀kùn-un iléèwé náà tí ó wà nínú Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́.

translation.en: Without crucial funds to continue, DCMA students and staff fear that the soulful sounds that flow through the hallways of this iconic institution that make these islands sing — may cease.
translation.yo: Láìsí owó tí ó tówó nílẹ̀ láti tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA àti òṣìṣẹ́ ń fòyà kí ìró amọ́kànbalẹ̀ tí ó ń sun jáde láti inúu gbọ̀ngán olókìkí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí tí ó mú erékùṣù yìí kọrin — leè wọ òkùnkùn.

translation.en: The school not only teaches and promotes traditional culture and heritage through music, but it's also home to a community of young musicians who seek alternatives to making a living as creatives.
translation.yo: Orin àti ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti àjogúnbá nìkan kọ́ ni ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà fi gbajúmọ̀, àmọ́ ó jẹ́ ilé fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ń wà ibi tí wọn yóò ti fi ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀.

translation.en: A DCMA student learns the qanun, a featured instrument in classical taarab songs. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
translation.yo: Akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA kan ń kọ́ qanun, ohun èlò orin ayédáadé orin taarab. Àwòrán láti iléèwé DCMA.

translation.en: "We [have started] to face a very challenging financial moment", said Alessia Lombardo, managing director of the DCMA, in an official DCMA video.
translation.yo: "A [ti bẹ̀rẹ̀] sí í ní rí ìdojúkọ ìgbà tí ó nira", alákòóso àgbàa DCMA, Alessia Lombardo sọ, nínúu àwòrán fídíò DCMA kan.

translation.en: "From now to the next six months, we are not sure that we can guarantee the salaries to our teachers and staff".
translation.yo: Láti ìsinsìnyí lọ títí di oṣù mẹ́fà sí àsìkò yìí, a kò rí àrídájú tí ó rinlẹ̀ wípé a ó leè san owó oṣù àwọn olùkọ́ni àti òṣìṣẹ́ẹ".

translation.en: At the moment, 19 master teachers and small core staff have gone without salaries for over three months as the school struggles to secure strong funding partnerships and explore sustainable funding models for a school.
translation.yo: Ní àkókò tí a wà yìí, àwọn àkàwé-gboyè olùkọ́ 19 àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ mìíràn ti ṣiṣẹ́ fún oṣù mẹ́ta gbáko láì gba owó lọ sílé nítorí àìsí owó nínúu kóló iléèwé.

translation.en: While the archipelago is known as a tourist destination for its pristine beaches and luxury hotels, the majority of local people struggle with high unemployment even as poverty has slightly decreased, according to The World Bank.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ilé Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ṣe ti ṣàlàyé wípé, pẹ̀lú bí a ti ṣe mọ agbègbè tí iléèwé náà wà fún ibi ìrìn-àjò ìgbafẹ́ nítorí àwọn etíkun àtijọ́ àti ilé ìtura olówó ńláńlá tí ó kángun síbẹ̀, ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ló ń bá àìníṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ pò ó pàápàá bí ìṣẹ́ ṣe ti gbé fúkẹ́ ju ti ìgbà kan lọ.

translation.en: For 17 years, the DCMA has worked tirelessly to promote and protect Zanzibar’s rich heritage and traditions through music.
translation.yo: Fún ọdún mẹ́tàdínlógún, DCMA ti ṣiṣẹ́ àṣekúdórógbó nípa lílo orin ṣe ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpamọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ àjogúnbá àti àṣà Zanzibar.

translation.en: The birthplace of legendary taarab singers Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, or Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is home to musical genres that emerged through cultural exchange and collaboration along the Swahili Coast for hundreds of years.
translation.yo: Orírun àwọn olóhùn-iyò akọrin taarab, Siti Binti Saad àti Fatuma Binti Baraka, tí a tún mọ̀ sí Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar ni ilé èyí-ò-jọ̀yìí orin tí ó ti inúu ìbàṣepapọ̀ àṣà àti àjọṣe ọlọ́dún gbọgbọrọ tí ó wà láàárín àwọn àdúgbò ẹ̀ka Swahili.

translation.en: Today, students can learn traditional musical genres like taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, along with instruments like drums, qanun and oud, as gatekeepers — and interpreters — of culture and tradition.
translation.yo: Láyé òde òní, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ leè kọ́ orin ìbílẹ̀ bíi taarab, ngoma àti kidumbak, pẹ̀lú àfikún àwọn ohun èlò ìkọrin bíi ìlù ní oníranànran, qanun àti oud, gẹ́gẹ́ bí alápamọ́ — àti òǹgbifọ̀ — àṣà àti ìṣe.

translation.en: Neema Surri, a violin player at the DCMA, has been studying the violin since the age of 9.
translation.yo: Neema Surri, a ta violin ní DCMA, ti ń kọ́ bí a ti ṣe ń ta ohun èlòo violin láti ọmọdún mẹ́sàn-án mẹ́nu lé ọ̀rọ̀ nínú àwòrán fídíò DCMA náà.

translation.en: "I know many young people who would like to study music but they can’t afford the minimal tuition fee because they are poor and unemployed", Surri said in the DCMA video.
translation.yo: "Mo mọ àwọn ọ̀dọ́mọdé tí ó máa nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí kíkọ́ orin ṣùgbọ́n wọn kò leè san owó ìmẹ̀kọ tí ó jẹ́ owó iléèwé nítorí wípé wọn kúṣẹ̀ẹ́ wọn kò sì ní iṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ".

translation.en: Students at the DCMA rehearse at the Old Customs House, where the school is based, in Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
translation.yo: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA ń fi ohun èlò ìkọrin olókùn tín-ín-rín kọrin nínú Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́, níbití iiléèwé náà fi ìkàlẹ̀ sí, ní Stone Town, Zanzibar, lọ́dún-un 2019. Àwòrán jẹ́ ti iléèwée DCMA.

translation.en: After completing DCMA workshops, certificate and diploma courses, many DCMA students go on to perform on world stages as award-winning bands and solo artists.
translation.yo: Ní ìparí àwọn ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA, tí wọ́n ti gba ìwé ẹ̀rí àti ní òpin ẹ̀kọ́ ọlọ́dún kan, púpọ̀ nínú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA ni ó ti di àgbà ọ̀jẹ́ tí wọ́n sì í ṣeré lórí ìtàgé kárí ayé.

translation.en: Zanzibar’s Amina Omar Juma, a former DCMA student and current DCMA teacher, recently returned from a tour in South Africa with her critically acclaimed, "Siti and the Band", known for "fusing the roots" by blending traditional taarab sounds with contemporary, layered rhythms.
translation.yo: Ọmọ bíbíi Zanzibar, tí ó jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA nígbà kan rí, tí ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ni ní iléèwé kan náà báyìí, Amina Omar Juma tòun ti ìlú mọ̀ọ́ká ẹgbẹ́ akọrin rẹ̀, tí ó ń "fi àṣà ìró orin ìbílẹ̀ " taarab papọ̀ mọ́ ti ìgbàlódélonígbàńlò kọrin, ìyẹn "Siti àti Ẹgbẹ́ ", ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ padà wọ̀lú láti ìrìnàjò orin kíkọ kan ní orílẹ̀-èdèe South Africa.

translation.en: She and other band members, also former DCMA students, released their first full album, "Fusing the Roots", in 2018, going on to perform at Sauti za Busara, East Africa's largest music festival, that same year.
translation.yo: Òun, àwọn díẹ̀ nínú ẹgbẹ́ akọrin rẹ̀ àti àpapọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA ní ìgbà kan rí ṣe àgbéjáde àwo orin wọn àkọ́kọ́, "Fusing the Roots", ní ọdún-un 2018, tí ó mú wọn oi ng o òǹwòran lára yá ní Sauti za Busara, tí í ṣe àjọ̀dún orin kíkọ tí ó gbàràdá jù lọ ní Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

translation.en: Here's Siti and the Band's "Nielewe" ("Understand Me") and music video, depicting scenes from Zanzibar while telling the story of a woman who experiences domestic abuse and dreams of life in music, much like Omar Juma's personal story:
translation.yo: Híhàyín ni orin Siti àti Ẹgbẹ́ “Nielewe” (“Gbó mi yéké”) àti àwòrán orin náà, tí ó ṣe àfihàn-an àwòrán-an, tí ó sọ ìtàn obìnrin kan tí ó ń rí ìdojúkọ abẹ̀-ilé, tí ó sì ń dárò ara rẹ̀. Ìtàn náà jọ ti Omar Juma fúnra rẹ̀:

translation.en: Read more: East African women in the music industry sing out against male domination
translation.yo: Kà síwájú sí i: Àwọn akọrin lóbìnrin Ìlà-Oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ kọrin tako àìfààyè gba obìnrin àwọn ọkùnrin.

translation.en: A history of cultural crossroads and collaboration
translation.yo: Ìtàn nípa àyálò àṣà àti àjọṣepọ̀

translation.en: Over 15,000 visitors have passed through the academy’s iconic building to enjoy live performances, workshops and classes and interact with passionate DCMA musicians who represent the future of Zanzibar culture and heritage, according to the DCMA.
translation.yo: Ó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dógún àlejò ni ó ti wo eré, gba ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti bá àwọn akọrin lóríṣiírísí ọjọ́ ọ̀la ní iléèwé olókìkí náà ní gbólóhùn rí.

translation.en: Drawing from a complex history of Indian, Arab and African exchange, the school celebrates the influence of "dhow countries", with inspiration from cultures that converged along the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.
translation.yo: Iléèwé náà ti ṣe àyálò àti àmúpapọ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àṣà "àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè dhow", tí ó wà ní ìtòsíi Òkun India àti Ọ̀gbùn-un Persia.

translation.en: The Omani Sultanate, a "major maritime force from the 17th to 19th centuries", shifted its seat of power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.
translation.yo: Agbègbèe Omani Sultanate, tí ó jẹ́ " ibi gbòógì àwọn alágbára atukọ̀ orí omi ní ọgọ́rùn-ún Ọdún-un kẹtàdínlógún sí kọkàndínlógún sẹ́yìn", gbé àga agbára rẹ̀ láti Muscat sí Zanzibar ní ọdún-un 1840.
