translation.en: With no light bulbs in the living room, he usually relied on light emitted from the rays of the TV screen.
translation.yo: Kò sí iná amọ́roro nínú yàrá ìgbàlejò, ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìtànṣán ẹ̀rọ àmóhùnmáwòrán ni ó máa ń fi ríran.

translation.en: He placed the object on the table and switched on the TV, only to discover, surprisingly, that the object he placed on the table had disappeared.
translation.yo: Ó gbé nǹkan àjèjì náà sí orí àga ìgbénǹkanlé, ó sì tan ẹ̀rọ àmóhùnmáwòrán, kàyéfì ló jẹ́ fún un, ohun tí ó gbé sórí àga di àwátì.

translation.en: He turned the entire room upside down and finally found it in a corner of the house.
translation.yo: Ó tú gbogbo ilé kí ó tó wá rí i ní kọ̀rọ̀ ilé.

translation.en: That night, he slept with the object under his pillow. He told Global Voices:
translation.yo: Lálẹ́ ọjọ́ yẹn, ó fi nǹkan àjèjì náà sábẹ́ ìgbèrí sùn. Ó sọ fún Ohùn Àgbáyé:

translation.en: I had a dream that I visited the sun.
translation.yo: Mo lálàá wí pé mo lọ sí inú oòrùn.

translation.en: When I got to the sun, it was dark and I was shown the alphabet in the form of lightning.
translation.yo: Nígbà tí mo débẹ̀, ó òkùnkùn ṣú bolẹ̀, a sì fi alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà hàn mí ní àpẹẹrẹ ìmọ́lẹ̀.

translation.en: Every time I slept, I had similar dreams, going from planet to planet, teaching people how to use the script...
translation.yo: Ìgbàkúùgbà tí mo bá sùn, àlá yìí kan náà ni ní ọ̀nà àrà, mò ń lọ láti agbègbè kan sí agbègbè mìíràn, tí mo sì ń kọ́ àwọn ènìyàn bí a ti ṣe ń lo ìṣọwọ́kọ tuntun náà...

translation.en: For three years, he kept dreaming about the alphabet, seeing visions consecutively, yet he did nothing about it.
translation.yo: Fún ọdún mẹ́ta, kò yé lálàá nípa alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà, kò yé ríran léraléra, síbẹ̀ kò ṣe nǹkankan sí i.

translation.en: This time around, in 2016, I went to the sun again, I met a man, Lámúrúdu, who taught me the sound of the alphabet, he afterward sanctioned me to go all over the globe teaching people the mastery of the symbols.
translation.yo: Lásìkò yìí, ní ọdún 2016, mo tún lọ sí inú oòrùn, mo ṣalábàápàdé ọkùnrin kan, Lámúrúdu, tí ó kọ́ mi ní ìró alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà, tí ó sì pa á láṣẹ fún mi pé kí tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìmọ̀ kíkọ àti kíkà àmì ìṣọwọ́kọ̀ náà kárí ayé.

translation.en: I usually look old in my dreams — and tired — when I wake up from sleep.
translation.yo: Mo máa ń jọ arúgbó lójú àlá — tí yóò sì rẹ̀ mí — bí mo bá jí lójú oorun.

translation.en: Things started to become scary for Chief Ògúntósìn — he began to feel weak, he told Global Voices.
translation.yo: Ó wá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní di ẹ̀rù fún Olóyè Ògúntósìn — ó ń rẹ̀ ẹ́ látinú wá, ó wí fún Ohùn Àgbáyé.

translation.en: He decided to narrate his dreams to a close spiritual adviser, Oníkòyí, king of Àjàṣẹ́ in Port-Novo, who counseled him to do what he was instructed in his dreams.
translation.yo: Ó pinnu láti rọ́ àwọn àlá náà fún Oníkòyí, Alájàṣẹ́ ti Àjàṣẹ́ ní Port-Novo, ẹni tí ó là á lóye pé kí ó ṣe bí a ti pa á láṣẹ lójú àlá.

translation.en: For this reason, he now travels from place to place in Yorùbáland to pass on his knowledge of the Odùduwà alphabet.
translation.yo: Látàrí ìdí èyí, ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò láti agbègbè kan dé òmíràn ní Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá láti tan ìmọ̀ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà.

translation.en: The following is a short video of teachers instructing students how to write the Odùduwà alphabet in a Benin classroom:
translation.yo: Àwòrán-àtohùn àwọn olùkọ́ni tí ó kọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ bí a ti ṣe ń kọ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà ní yàrá-ìgbẹ̀kọ́ kan ní Bẹ̀nẹ̀:

translation.en: Promoting theYorùbá alphabet
translation.yo: Ìgbélárugẹ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Yorùbá náà

translation.en: In 2017, Chief Ògúntósìn, in the company of prominent traditional rulers in Yorùbáland and the diaspora, paid a visit to Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, the one-time governor of Nigeria’s Ọ̀ṣun State, in Òṣogbo, the state capital, to solicit support for his newly found Odùduwà alphabet.
translation.yo: Lọ́dún 2017, Olóyè Ògúntósìn, pẹ̀lú àwọn ọba Aláṣẹ igbá-kejì òrìṣà Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá nílé àti lẹ́yìn odi, ṣe àbẹ̀wó to sí Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, ẹni tí ó fi ìgbà kan rí jẹ́ alákòóso Ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀ṣun, ní olú ìpínlẹ̀ náà th Òṣogbo, e one- èdè Nàìjíríà, láti béèrè fún àtìlẹ́yìn fún alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà tuntun náà.

translation.en: Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá now serves as the Minister of the Federal Ministry of Interior of Nigeria.
translation.yo: Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá ni Mínísítà fún Ètò Abélé fún orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ní sáà ti a wà yìí.

translation.en: A reminder letter was sent to the governor of Osun state after promises made to teach the new alphabet have gone unfulfilled.
translation.yo: Ìwé tí a kọ ránṣẹ́ sí gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀ṣun ní ìrántí àwọn ìpinnu kíkọ́ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà tí kò tíì wá sí ìmúṣẹ.

translation.en: Three years later, regrettably, verbal promises made by former governor Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá to teach the discovered alphabet in elementary schools across southwest Nigeria have gone unfulfilled.
translation.yo: Ọdún mẹ́ta ti lọ, ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́, ìlérí tí gómìnà àná Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá ṣe láti rí dájú wí pé alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà jẹ́ kíkọ́ ni àwọn iléèwé tí ó ń bẹ ní Ìwọ̀-oòrùn gúúsù ilẹ̀ Nàìjíríà kò tíì di múmú ṣẹ.

translation.en: In a bid to make the Odùduwà alphabet popular, Chief Ògúntósìn has written a book and produced a documentary on the orthography — with snippets uploaded on the internet for public viewing — as well as an abandoned cartoon project which did not see the light of day due to lack of funds.
translation.yo: Lójúnà kí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà ó ba di ìlúmọ̀ọ́ká, Olóyè Ògúntósìn ti kọ ìwé kan, ó sì ti ká àwòrán-àtohùn alálàyé kan tí ó tú pẹrẹpẹ́ẹ̀rẹ̀ ìṣọwọ́kọ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà sílẹ̀ — fún mùtúmùwà láti wò ní abalaabala lórí ayélujára — bákan náà ni ẹ̀patìrì iṣẹ́ akọ́nilọ́gbọ́n kàtúùnù fún àwọn èwe tí kò s'ówó láti parí i rẹ̀ náà ò gbẹ́yìn.

translation.en: Chief Ògúntósìn also uses YouTube, WhatsApp and Facebook Groups: “Ẹ̀kọ́ Aèébàèjìogbè Odùduwà” and "Odùduwà Alphabets" to promote and teach interested language learners.
translation.yo: Olóyè Ògúntósìn ń lo gbàgbé YouTube, WhatsApp àti Ẹgbẹ́ orí Facebook: "Ẹ̀kọ́ Aèébáèjìogbè Odùduwà" àti “Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà” fi ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti kọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí kíkọ́ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ náà.

translation.en: He calls on all stakeholders to support the promotion of his linguistic discovery that will checkmate Western writing culture and give the Yorùbá people their deserved identity in terms of language development.
translation.yo: Ó rọ gbogbo ẹni tí ọ̀ràn kan láti dìde sí ti ìgbélárugẹ àwárí tí yóò gbá ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Àmúnisìn tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ tí yóò sì fún ìran Yorùbá ní ìdánimọ̀ tí ó tọ́ tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdàgbàsókè èdè.

translation.en: A kind-hearted Yorùbá man, Sunday Adéníyì, supported the cause by printing 1,000 copies of the "Aèébàèjìogbè Odùduwà Alphabets" exercise book for primary school pupils.
translation.yo: Ọkùnrin onínúure kan, Sunday Adéníyì, ṣe agbátẹrù ìtẹ̀jáde 1,000 ẹ̀da ìwé ìgbẹ̀kọ́ "Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Aèébáèjìogbè Odùduwà" fún àwọn ọmọ iléèwé alákọ̀ọ̀bẹ̀rẹ̀.

translation.en: Read more: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yorùbá — and other languages — wrong
translation.yo: Kà sí i: Sísọnù sínú ògbufọ̀: Ìdí tí Atúmọ̀ Google ṣe ń kùnà — nínú títúmọ̀ èdè Yorùbá — àti àwọn èdè mìíràn

translation.en: Copies of the educational pamphlets were printed in Igbo, Hausa, English, and French languages respectively. However, more support is crucial to disseminate the alphabet to a wider audience.
translation.yo: Ẹ̀da ìwé ẹ̀kọ́ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà wà ní èdè Igbo, Hausa, English, àti Faransé lẹ́sẹẹsẹ. Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àtìlẹ́yìn kì í pọ̀ jù fún ìpínkárí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà.

translation.en: The Odùduwà alphabet is a welcome development.
translation.yo: Ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó mú ìwúrí dání ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà.

translation.en: Nevertheless, the shift from writing in Latin to the new system will be a major challenge.
translation.yo: Ṣùgbọ́n, sísún láti ìlànà Látíìnì sí ìlànà tuntun ni yóò mú ìpèníjà ńlá lọ́wọ́.

translation.en: That said, the Odùduwà alphabet is a great step in the right direction toward the development and growth of the Yorùbá language — in what Yorùbá people will call their own.
translation.yo: Kò jẹ́ bó ṣe jẹ́, ohun tí yóò mú ìlọsíwájú àti ìdàgbàsókè bá èdè Yorùbá ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà — ohun tí ìran Yorùbá yóò pè ni tiwa-ń-tiwa.

translation.en: Yorùbá loanwords: How languages evolve
translation.yo: Ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá: Bí èdè ṣe yí padà

translation.en: Do you say àkàrà or bean cake?
translation.yo: Ṣé àkàrà ni ò ń pè àbí bean cake?

translation.en: Àkàrà or Nigerian bean cake is a staple breakfast in Nigeria, July 11, 2013. Photo by Atimukoh via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
translation.yo: Àkàrà tàbí beans cake ní Nàìjíríà jẹ́ oúnjẹ àárọ̀ ní Nàìjíríà, ọjọ́ 11, oṣù kéje, ọdún 2013. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Atimukoh láti orí i Wikimedia Commons, àṣẹ CC BY 2.0.

translation.en: Relationships between languages have existed for hundreds of years.
translation.yo: Àjọṣepọ̀ láàárín onírúurú èdè ti wà láti ayébáyé.

translation.en: Think of the word "restaurant," borrowed from the French language into English.
translation.yo: Fún àkàwé, kí á wo gbólóhùn bí i "restaurant," tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ tí a yá láti inú èdè Faransé wá sínú èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

translation.en: Today, this loanword — a word adopted from one language into another without translation — circulates in English as if it was never borrowed.
translation.yo: Lóde òní, ọ̀rọ̀-àyálò yìí — ìyẹn gbólóhùn tí a gbà lò láti inú èdè kan sí inú èdè mìíràn láì tú ìmọ̀ rẹ̀ — kò l'óǹkà nínú èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì àfi bí ẹni pé kì í ṣe ọ̀rọ̀ tí a yá lò.

translation.en: These linguistic borrowings can be attributed to immigration, commerce, and trade as people were exposed to a wide range of ethnolinguistic environments.
translation.yo: Àwọn èdè àyálò wọ̀nyí wáyé látàrí àbápàdé onírúurú ènìyàn kárí ayé, bí wọ́n ṣe ń ṣíkiri, ṣe ọrọ̀ Ajé, àti káràkátà.

translation.en: Through these interactions, people were exposed to various linguistic contexts, and words and phrases were borrowed to accommodate these encounters.
translation.yo: Látàrí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tí ó wáyé láàárín àwọn onírúurú ènìyàn wọ̀nyí, èdè wọnú èdè, gbólóhùn àti àpólà ọ̀rọ̀ di àyálò.

translation.en: The Yorùbá case is no exception.
translation.yo: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí kò yọ ìran Yorùbá sílẹ̀.

translation.en: Spoken widely by about 40 million speakers in Nigeria, Yorùbá language has been influenced by the English language spoken by the British, who held colonial power in Nigeria from 1914 to 1960.
translation.yo: Ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ènìyàn 40 tíó ń fọ èdè Yorùbá ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, irú èdè Yorùbá ti dàpọ̀ mọ́ ṣapala èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, tí í ṣe èdè ìjọba amúnisìn àná láti ọdún 1914 sí 1960.

translation.en: More than half of the vocabulary words used in Yorùbá are borrowed from English. Think of the word "cup", it was domesticated as kó̩ò̩pù.
translation.yo: Ó tó ìdajì gbólóhùn èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí a yà lò nínú èdè Yorùbá. Kí a wo ọ̀rọ̀ bí i "cup" Ó di kó̩ò̩pù.

translation.en: The word "phone" is fóònù, "ball" is bó̩ò̩lù, and "television" is te̩lifís̩ó̩ò̩nù, among others.
translation.yo: A pe "phone" ní fóònù, "ball" di bó̩ò̩lù, "television" ni te̩lifís̩ó̩ò̩nù, àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

translation.en: These English words that were "loaned" to Yorùbá expanded its vocabulary over time.
translation.yo: Àwọn gbólóhùn "àyálò" wọ̀nyí mú èdè Yorùbá fẹjú sí i.

translation.en: There are also instances of the Yorùbá language borrowing words from the Hausa language, spoken by 44 million people in the northern part of Nigeria.
translation.yo: Bákan náà ni àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò inú èdè Hausa tí àwọn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 44 ènìyàn ní Àríwá ilẹ̀ Nàìjíríà ń sọ lọ sua.

translation.en: This language borrows heavily from Arabic, as well, with words like àlùbáríkà ("blessing"), àlùbó̩sà ("onion") and wàhálà ("trouble").
translation.yo: Èdè yìí yá ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye ọ̀rọ̀ lò láti inú èdè Lárúbáwá, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ bí i àlùbáríkà ("ìbùkún"), àlbásà ("àlùbọ́sà") àti wàhálà ("ìyọnu").

translation.en: The beauty of Yorùbá loanwords is that speakers now use them in their day-to-day conversations as they get absorbed into the language.
translation.yo: Ohun tí ó jẹ́ ìwúrí ní ti àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá ni bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe ń lò wọ́n nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ lójoojúmọ́ bí wọ́n ṣe ń ṣàn wọ inú èdè náà.

translation.en: It is not uncommon to hear people say, Bá o̩mo̩ ye̩n mú bó̩ò̩lu è̩  or "Help the child take the ball" in English.
translation.yo: Wà á gbọ́ gbólóhùn bí i, Bá o̩mo̩ ye̩n mú bó̩ò̩lu è̩ tàbí "Help the child take the ball" lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

translation.en: Although the underlined word bó̩ò̩lu is not native to the Yorùbá language, speakers manage to make it fit.
translation.yo: Adi, ọmọ-ọ̀rọ̀ tí a falà sí lábẹ́ bó̩ò̩lu jẹ́ tiwantiwa nínú èdè Yorùbá, àwọn aṣàfọ̀ mọ bí wọ́n ṣe ń lò ó.

translation.en: One of the challenges with the Yorùbá language with regard to loanwords is that native speakers themselves love translating Yorùbá words into English and using them in sentences instead of the original Yorùbá word.
translation.yo: Ìpèníjà kan tí èdè Yorùbá ní nípa ti ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò ò ju ti ògbufọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ wuuru tí àwọn aṣàfọ̀ èdè Yorùbá máa ń ṣe láti túmọ̀ àwọn gbólóhùn èdè Yorùbá sí ti Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí wọ́n máa ń lò nínú ìpèdè dípò ojúlówó èdè Yorùbá.

translation.en: An example is the word àkàrà  — most Yorùbá speakers translate it to bean cake in daily interactions —, especially with foreigners.
translation.yo: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, àkàrà — tí àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ti túmọ̀ sí bean cake — pàápàá nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro-ọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú àlejò.

translation.en: Using words in their original forms helps ensure that culture — kept alive through language — continues to thrive.
translation.yo: Lílo ọ̀rọ̀ ní èdè pọ́nbélé máa ń mú kí àṣà — ó gbòòrò — tí yóò sí máa jẹ́ kí èdè ó di ìtẹ́wọ́gbà.

translation.en: For instance, no one calls Japan’s sushi by any other name — sushi is sushi.
translation.yo: Bí a bá wò ó báyìí, kò s'ẹ́ni jẹ́ pe sushi Japan lórúkọ mìíràn — sushi ni sushi ń jẹ́.

translation.en: If this was the case for many Yorùbá words, too, its language and culture could flourish beyond Nigeria and the Yorùbá-speaking world.
translation.yo: Bí èyí bá rí bẹ́ẹ̀ fún àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ Yorùbá náà, èdè àti àṣà rẹ̀, yóò gbilẹ̀ kọjá orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà àti ibi tí wọ́n ti ń fọ èdè Yorùbá kárí ayé.

translation.en: For example, àmàlà is a famous Yorùbá food, even in the diaspora.
translation.yo: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, àmàlà jẹ́ oúnjẹ tí ó ilẹ̀ Yorùbá lókìkí, pàápàá ní òkè òkun.

translation.en: This word could easily find its way into the lexicon of other languages if Yorùbá speakers insisted on it.
translation.yo: Gbólóhùn yìí ti rá pálá wọnú ìlò ọ̀rọ̀ èdè mìíràn bí àwọn aṣàfọ̀ Yorùbá bá tẹnu mọ́ ọn.

translation.en: Translating it to "yam flour" lessens its status and linguistic root — its "Yorubaness."
translation.yo: Títúmọ̀ rẹ̀ sí "yam flour" dín agbára ìpèdè náà kù — yóò sọ "ipò Yorùbá nù."

translation.en: Think of the anglicized Yorùbá word "fanimorious", which is becoming more popular and appears in the Urban Dictionary.
translation.yo: Bí a bá wo gbólóhùn èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí a yí padà sí èdè Yorùbá "fanimorious", tí ó ti ń lókìkí tí ó sì ti wà nínú Ìwé Ìtumọ̀ Ìgbàlódé.

translation.en: It means "appealing", or "beautiful", and comes from the word fanimó̩ra in Yorùbá.
translation.yo: Ó túmọ̀ sí “bójúmu,” tàbí “rẹwà,” tí ó súyọ láti fanimó̩ra tí í ṣe gbólóhùn Yorùbá.

translation.en: This could be phono-morphological: Yorùbá language does not allow final word consonants and consonant clusters.
translation.yo: Èyí f'ara pẹ́ ìbáṣepọ̀ fonọ́lọ́jì àti mọfọ́lọ́jì: èdè Yorùbá kì í fàyè gba ìhunpọ̀ kọ̀nsónántì àti kí ọ̀rọ̀ parí pẹ̀lú kọ̀nsónántì.

translation.en: As a result, the English suffix -ious was added to the Yorùbá root word.
translation.yo: Torí ìdí èyí, a fi àfòmọ́ ìparí -ious èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì kún ọ̀rọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ Yorùbá.

translation.en: However, the fact remains that the word stems from the Yorùbá language. This is a win for the Yorùbá.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, òtítọ́ farahàn wípé láti ara èdè Yorùbá ni ó ti sú yọ. Ìgbéga ni èyí jẹ́ fún Yor Yorùbá.

translation.en: Recently, several other Nigerian English words were added to the Oxford English Dictionary.
translation.yo: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́ yìí, ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì bí a ti ṣe ń lò ó ní Nàìjíríà di àfikún nínú ìwé ìtúmọ̀ èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti Oxford.

translation.en: Yorùbá will make giant strides only if its speakers contribute to its growth; Its usage in the media is also important as the world becomes increasingly more digitized.
translation.yo: Ọpọ́n èdè Yorùbá yóò sún síwájú bí àwọn tó ń fọ èdè náà bá lọ́wọ́ sí ìdàgbàsókè rẹ̀; ìlò rẹ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìkọ̀ròyìn pọn dandan ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú bí ayé ṣe ń lu jára wọn bí ajere lóde òní.

translation.en: Consequently, this will spur further research on the Niger-Congo language.
translation.yo: Ní ìparí, èyí yóò túbọ̀ mú kí iṣẹ́ ìwádìí èdè Niger-Congo ó rinlẹ̀.

translation.en: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yorùbá — and other languages — wrong
translation.yo: Sísọnù sínú ògbufọ̀: Ìdí tí Atúmọ̀ Google ṣe ń kùnà — nínú títúmọ̀ èdè Yorùbá — àti àwọn èdè mìíràn

translation.en: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong
translation.yo: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ògbufọ̀ tí ẹ̀rọ ṣe ni kò nítumọ̀.

translation.en: Wikimedia User Group Nigeria, October 2018 via Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.
translation.yo: Aṣàmúlò Ẹgbẹ́ Wikimedia Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún 2018 láti orí Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.

translation.en: The English language has dominated online discourse as the "universal" language of communication since the inception of the internet.
translation.yo: Èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti jẹ gàba lórí ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ tí ó ń wáyé ní orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere gẹ́gẹ́ bí èdè "gbogbo àgbáyé" fún ìtàkùrọ̀sọ láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára.

translation.en: As of February 2020, over half of the websites on the internet are in English, according to WebTech3.
translation.yo: Nínú oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2020, gẹ́gẹ́ bí WebTech3 ti ṣe fi hàn, ìdajì ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyé tó wà lórí ayélujára ni a kọ ní èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

translation.en: But as more people get online who speak different languages, it has sparked a linguistic digital revolution — immediate access to English translations of multiple languages with the click of a button.
translation.yo: Àmọ́ bí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó ń sọ oríṣìíríṣìí èdè àgbáyé ṣe ń bọ́ sórí ayélukára-bí-ajere, ó ṣẹ́ ẹtà ìjà fún èdè ẹni — ìráàyè sí ìṣògbufọ̀ sí onírúurú èdè tí yóò ṣẹ̀ ní mọnawáà.

translation.en: Many tech companies have recently put effort into documenting non-English words on the internet, paving the way for the digitization of multiple languages. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT and  ALC are examples of companies and start-ups that have been trying to marry technology with non-English languages.
translation.yo: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iléeṣẹ́ onímọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe iṣẹ́ ribiribi ní ti ìṣàkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tí kì í ṣe èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì sórí ayélujára, tí ó ń ṣe olùlànà onírúurú èdè lórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá lọ́nà ìgbàlódé. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT àti ALC jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ńlá àti àwọn iléeṣẹ́ kéréje tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ tí ó ti mú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn èdè tí kì í ṣe èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

translation.en: In late February 2020, Google announced that it would add five new languages to its Google Translate services, including Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen and Odia, after a four-year hiatus on adding new languages.
translation.yo: Kí oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2020 ó tó tẹnu bepo, Google filọ̀ wípé òun yóò fi èdè tuntun márùn-ún kún iṣẹ́ Atúmọ̀ Google rẹ̀, àwọn èdè náà ni Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen àti Odia, lẹ́yìn ìsinmi ọdún mẹ́rin tí wọ́n fi èdè tuntun kún un kẹ́yìn.

translation.en: A man looks perplexed while reading a text online. Photo by Oladimeji Ajegbile, open-source via Pexels.
translation.yo: Ọkùnrin kan ń wò bí ẹni tí ó nídààmú nígbà tí ó ń ka gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ayélujára. Àwòránlláti ọwọ́ Ọládiméjì Ajégbilẹ̀, àṣẹ-àtúnlò láti orí Pexels.

translation.en: But have you ever clicked on the translation option and realized that the English translation is, at best, just OK?
translation.yo: Àmọ́ ṣe o ti ṣíra tẹ àṣàyàn ìtumọ̀ rí tí ó ṣàkíyèsí wípé, bákan, ló dára jù lọ?

translation.en: And at worst, not accurate at all?
translation.yo: Bákan náà, ló kù díẹ̀ káàtó, kò ṣe déédéé?

translation.en: There are many controversies and difficulties when it comes to doing this kind of language translation and access work.
translation.yo: Orísìírísìí àríyànjiyàn àti ìṣòro ló máa ń wáyé bí ó bá kan irú ìtumọ̀ èdè báyìí àti rírí i lò.

translation.en: Twitter offers Yorùbá language translation into English via Google Translate as much as possible, and usually, the outcome isn’t totally bad — perhaps a few words are correct.
translation.yo: Twitter máa ń ṣe ìtumọ̀ èdè Yorùbá sí èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì nípasẹ̀ lílo Atúmọ̀ Google bí ó ti ṣe fàyè gbà wọ́n, tí àbájáde rẹ̀ sì kù díẹ̀ káàtó nígbàgbogbo — tí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ kọ̀ọ̀kan sì ṣe déédéé.

translation.en: The reason for these challenges is that tech companies usually collect their linguistic data for English translation sourced from the internet.
translation.yo: Ohun tí ó fa àwọn ìpeníjà wọ̀nyí ó ju pé orí ayélujára ni àwọn iléeṣẹ́ onímọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ti máa ń ṣe àkójọ èdè wọn for tí wọ́n ń fi ṣe ògbufọ̀ gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀.

translation.en: This data may work for some languages, but languages like Yorùbá and Ìgbò, two main languages from Nigeria, are challenging, due to the inadequate or inaccurate accent marks to indicate tones on these words.
translation.yo: Àwọn àkójọ gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí lè ṣiṣẹ́ fún àwọn èdè kan, àmọ́ èdè bí i Yorùbá àti Ìgbò, jẹ́ èdè méjì ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, tí ìpèníjà yìí bá, látàrí àìpọ̀tó gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ àti gbólóhùn tí a ò yán lórílábẹ́ dáadáa tí yóò tọ́ka sí ìró ohùn.

translation.en: In response to why it has taken Google four years to add five new languages, a company spokesperson explained:
translation.yo: Láti fèsì sí ohun tí ó fa sábàbí tí ó fi gba Google ní ọdún mẹ́rin kí ó tó ṣe àfikún èdè tuntun márùn-ún kún tilẹ̀, agbẹnusọ iléeṣẹ́ náà ṣe ìṣípayá:

translation.en: Google Translate learns from existing translations found on the web, and when languages don’t have an abundance of web content, it’s been difficult for our system to support them effectively.
translation.yo: Orí ìtakùn àgbáyé ni Atúmọ̀ Google ti máa ń ṣa gbólóhùn tí a ti túmọ̀ jọ, àmọ́ bí èdè kò bá ní gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó pọ̀ tó lórí ayélujára, ó nira fún ẹ̀rọ wa láti ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn tí ó lákaakì fún irú àwọn èdè bẹ́ẹ̀

translation.en: However, due to recent advances in our machine learning technology, and active involvement from our Google Translate Community members, we’ve been able to add support for these languages.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, látàrí ìlọsíwájú àbùdá kíkọ́ ẹ̀rọ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wa, àti àwọn aṣiṣẹ́ Ìtumọ̀ Google lọ́fẹ̀ẹ́, ecent advances in our machine a ti fi àtìlẹ́yìn fún àwọn èdè wọ̀nyí.

translation.en: Also, most people are not so good with the orthographies — or spellings — in these languages.
translation.yo: Bákan náà, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ni kò mọ bí a ṣe ń kọ ọ̀rọ̀ dájúdánu — tàbí pípe ọmọ-ọ̀rọ̀ — inú àwọn èdè wọ̀nyí.

translation.en: As a result, good translations don’t compute because these errors are not flagged as inadequate.
translation.yo: Torí náà, ògbufọ̀ tí ó kúnjú òṣùwọ̀n kò jẹ́ àkópọ̀ nítorí kò sí bí a ṣe lè dá àwọn àṣìṣe wọ̀nyí mọ̀.

translation.en: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong, especially words that are culturally nuanced.
translation.yo: Púpọ̀ nínú ògbufọ̀ tí ẹ̀rọ ṣe ni kò ní ìtumọ̀, pàápàá jù lọ àwọn gbólóhùn tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ àṣà tí ó ní ju ìtúmọ̀ kan ṣoṣo lọ.

translation.en: For example, Yorùbá words ayaba and obabìnrin have their meanings situated in a cultural context.
translation.yo: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, gbólóhùn Yorùbá bí i ayaba àti ọbabìnrin ní ìtumọ̀ tó yàtọ̀.

translation.en: Most machines translate both words as "queen".
translation.yo: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ní í máa tú ìmọ̀ gbólóhùn méjèèjì sí "queen".

translation.en: However, from a traditional-cum-cultural vantage point, it is essential to note that the meanings of ayaba and obabìnrin are different: Ọbabìnrin means "queen" in English while ayaba is "wife of the king".
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, tí a bá ti ọ̀nà ìṣe-àti-àsà wò ó, ó ṣe kókó láti sọ wí pé ìtúmọ̀ ayaba and ọbabìnrin yàtọ̀ síra wọn: Ọbabìnrin túmọ̀ sí "queen" lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì nígbà tí ayaba jẹ́ "wife of the king".

translation.en: Even with these translation complications, technology has helped with the advancement of  African languages in digital spaces, spurring the coinage of new words.
translation.yo: Pẹ̀lú àwọn àìṣedéédéé wọ̀nyí, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ lórí àwọn gbàgede orí ayélujára, tí ó ti mú ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀ tuntun wáyé.

translation.en: African languages have grown with the influx of new gadgets like smartphones and tablets, as new words are coined to name these new technological tools and concepts.
translation.yo: Èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti gòkè àgbà látàrí àwọn lílo àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìgbàlódé tuntun bí i ẹ̀rọ-ìléwọ́ àti ẹ̀rọ ọpọ́n ayárabíàṣá, tí ó sì ń bí àwọn gbólóhùn tuntun tí a fi ń pe àwọn irinṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tuntun wọ̀nyí.

translation.en: This process has thus expanded the usage and functionality of these languages.
translation.yo: Èyí sì ti fẹ bí a ti ṣe ń lo àwọn èdè wọ̀nyí lójú.

translation.en: With the emergence of new technologies, the vocabularies of many African languages have become more sophisticated.
translation.yo: Látàrí àwọn ẹ̀rọ tuntun wọ̀nyí, ìpèdè ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti lé kún sí i.

translation.en: For instance, the Yorùbá language has some tech-influenced words such as erọ amúlétutù ("air conditioner"), erọ Ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ("phone") and erọ Ìlọta ("grinder").
translation.yo: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, èdè Yorùbá ní àwọn gbólóhùn tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ bí i ẹ̀rọ-amúlétutù ("air conditioner"), erọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ("phone") and ẹ̀rọ-ìlọta ("grinder").

translation.en: Similarly, the Igbo language has words such as ekwè nti ("telephone") and ugbọ̀ àlà ("vehicle").
translation.yo: Ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, èdè Igbo náà ní ọ̀rọ̀ bí i ekwè nti ("telephone") àti ugbọ̀ àlà ("vehicle").

translation.en: These societies have given these gadgets names based on the functions they perform.
translation.yo: A ṣẹ̀dá àwọn orúkọ yìí ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń ṣe.

translation.en: In courses on broadcasting and advertisement in Yorùbá, students learn that most people call TV erọ Amóhùnmáwòrán.
translation.yo: Nínú ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ àti ètò ìpolówó ọjà lédè Yorùbá, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ti kọ́ wí pé ẹ̀rọ-amóhùnmáwòrán ni oọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn ń pe TV.

translation.en: This coinage generates many questions and opinions — some students argue that video cameras and recorders can also be called erọ amóhùnmáwòrán based on their functionalities.
translation.yo: Ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀ yìí fa àwọn onírúurú ìbéèrè àti èrò — àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kan jiyàn wí pé a lè pe ẹ̀rọ-ayàwòrán náà ní ẹ̀rọ-amóhùnmáwòrán nítorí iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń ṣe.

translation.en: These linguistic challenges in the tech space are healthy for languages — it stimulates critical thinking for both linguistic and tech advancement.
translation.yo: Àwọn ìpèníjà t'ó tara ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wá yìí ni yóò mú ìdàgbàsókè bá èdè — ó máa ń fa àròjìnlẹ̀ fún ìgbéga èdè àti ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ.

translation.en: In 2019, Google opened its first AI research center in Accra, Ghana, focused on improving “Google Translate's ability to capture African languages more precisely,” according to CNN.
translation.yo: Lọ́dún 2019, gẹ́gẹ́ bí CNN ti ṣe ròyìn, Google ṣí ibiṣẹ́ ìwádìí AI àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀ sí Accra, Ghana, tí ó ń lépa láti mú kí "Atúmọ̀ Google ó gba àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ jọ kí ó lọ geere".

translation.en: Research scientist Moustapha Cisse, who heads Google's AI work in Africa, believes that "a continent with more than 2,000 dialects deserves to be better served," as reported by CNN.
translation.yo: Onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ nípa iṣẹ́ ìwádìí Moustapha Cisse, tó jẹ́ olórí iṣẹ́ Google AI ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, nígbàgbọ́ wí pé ó tọ́ sí "ilẹ̀ tí ó ní ju ẹ̀ka-èdè 2,000 lọ láti jẹ́ àǹfààní iṣẹ́," — CNN jábọ̀.

translation.en: Mozilla and BMZ recently announced their cooperation to open up voice technology for African languages. With initiatives like this, there is more to show in the future with regards to studies in African languages.
translation.yo: Mozilla àti BMZ kéde àjùmọ̀ṣe wọn láti ṣe agbátẹrù iṣẹ́ àkànṣe tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lórí ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ alohùn fún thei èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀. Pẹ̀lú àwọn iṣẹ́ àtinudá bí eléyìí, ọjọ́ iwájú ìwádìí èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ dára.

translation.en: Churches in Greece and North Macedonia refuse to modify rituals conducive to the spread of COVID-19
translation.yo: Àwọn Iléèjọsìn ní Greece àti Àríwá Macedonia kọ̀ láti yí ọwọ́ àwọn ìlànà-ìsìn wọn padà k'ó ba má fàyè gba àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn COVID-19 t'ó ń ràn ká

translation.en: "Institution of the Eucharist", a 1442 painting by Fra Angelico. Public Domain photo via Wikipedia.
translation.yo: "Àjọ Oúnjẹ Alẹ́ Olúwa", àwòrán tí a kùn lódà ní 1442 láti ọwọ́ Fra Angelico. Àwòrán tí kò ní olóhun láti orí Wikipedia.

translation.en: While the number of people with COVID-19 steadily increases in the Balkans, a few Christian churches have refused to change liturgical practices that can contribute to the spread of the coronavirus.
translation.yo: Bí àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19 ṣe ń pọ̀ọ́ sí i ní Balkans, àwọn ilé ìjọsìn kan kò yí ọwọ́ àwọn ìlànà ìsìn tí ó lè mú kí àrùn Coronavirus ó ràn bí i pápá inú ọyẹ́ padà.

translation.en: The ritual known as the Holy Communion or Eucharist has Orthodox Christian worshipers drinking consecrated wine by a shared spoon, while Catholics eat thin slices of bread directly from the hand of the priest.
translation.yo: Ìlànà ìsìn tí a mọ̀ sí Jíjẹara àti mímu ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa tàbí Oúnjẹ Ìkẹyìn ní èyí tí àwọn ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì tí ó ń tẹ̀lé ìlànà ìsìn àtijọ́ yóò máa pín wáìnì tí a ti sọ di mímọ́ mu pẹ̀lú ṣíbí kan náà, àwọn Ìjọ Àgùdàá máa ń jẹ ẹ̀bẹ àkàrà fẹ́lẹ́fẹ́lẹ́ tí wọ́n fi ẹnu gbà lọ́wọ́ àlùfáà.

translation.en: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding large gatherings and increased levels of personal hygiene and sanitation in order to minimize the spread of the virus by touch, exchange of bodily fluids, and through the air.
translation.yo: Àjọ Ìlera Àgbáyé (WHO) rọ̀ wá láti jìnà gbégbérégbé sí ibi tí àwọn èròó bá pitì sí, kí a sì káràmásíkì sí ìlera ara wa kí á ba dín àrànká àrùn ẹ̀jẹ̀ tí ènìyàn lè kó nípasẹ̀ ìfọwọ́kàn, ìfarakan omi tó sun lára ẹlòmíràn, àti láti inú afẹ́fẹ́.

translation.en: In an official statement dated March 9, the Greek Orthodox Church said it will not be modifying the ritual to comply with safety measures.
translation.yo: Nínú àtẹ̀jáde ọjọ́ 9, Iléèjọsìn Àtijọ́ Greek sọ wí pé òun kò ní yí ọwọ́ ìlànà-ìsìn padà kí ó bá ìgbésẹ̀ ààbò mu.

translation.en: It also added that the "coronavirus is not transmitted via Holy Communion, and the faithful should pray against the spread of the deadly virus".
translation.yo: Bákan náà ni ó sọ wí pé "a kò leè kó ààrùn coronavirus láti ara Jíjẹ ara-àti-mímu-ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa, àti pé kí àwọn ọmọ Ọlọ́run ó gbàdúrà gidi nítorí ààrùn apànìyàn náà".

translation.en: GOC bishop Klimis, the Metropolitan of Peristeri, a suburban municipality near Athens, said that those who believe the virus could spread via religious rituals are blasphemers:
translation.yo: Bíṣọ́ọ̀pù ti GOC Klimis, ti Àárín gbùngbùn Peristeri, lábẹ́ agbègbè tó sún mọ́ Athens, sọ wí pé ọ̀rọ̀-òdì sí Olúwa ni bí ẹnikẹ́ni bá sọ pé ìlànà ẹ̀sìn lè mú kí ààrùn ó ràn:

translation.en: The Holy Communion is life.
translation.yo: Ìyè ni Ara-jíjẹ àti ẹ̀jẹ̀ mímu.

translation.en: It is a miracle.
translation.yo: Iṣẹ́ ìyanu ni.

translation.en: It is a blasphemy to believe that the virus can be transmitted by receiving Holy Communion.
translation.yo: Ọ̀rọ̀-òdì sí Olúwa ni láti ní ìgbàgbọ́ wí pé ènìyàn lè tara Jíjẹ ara-àti-mímu-ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa kó ààrùn.

translation.en: There have been 89 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Greece, with no deaths so far.
translation.yo: Ènìyàn 89 ló ti lùgbàdì COVID-19 ní Greece, láìsí ẹni tó kù.

translation.en: Greek authorities, who have recently closed schools and prohibited gatherings in efforts to prevent transmission, urged the Church to reconsider.
translation.yo: Àwọn aláṣẹ Greek, tí ó ti ṣán àwọn iléèwé pa, tí ó sì ti f'òfin de àpéjọ lójú ọ̀nà àti dènà àjàkálẹ̀, rọ Iléèjọsìn náà láti ṣe àtúnwò.

translation.en: But state officials themselves seem to be ignoring those concerns. On a major religious holiday last Sunday, the president and some government ministers attended a public mass.
translation.yo: Àmọ́ àwọn aṣojú ìjọba tìkarawọn ń tàpá sí òfin ìdènà ààrùn yìí. Lọ́jọ́ ìsinmi ajẹmẹ́sìn kan lọ́jọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀ tó kọjá, ààrẹ àti àwọn onípò nínú ìṣèjọba rẹ̀ lọ sí ìsìn kan.

translation.en: In neighboring North Macedonia, the Macedonian Orthodox Church – Ohrid  Archbishopric seems to be following a similar path.
translation.yo: Ní ìlú tó múlé gbe Greece, ó jọ pé North Macedonia, Iléèjọsìn Àtijọ́ ti Macedonia – Ohrid Archbishopric náà ń tọ ipasẹ̀ kan náà.

translation.en: Although the church has not yet issued any official statement about the outbreak, it has continued to conduct the Holy Communion normally.
translation.yo: Bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé Iléèjọsìn náà kò tíì ṣe ìfilọ̀ kankan nípa àjàkálẹ̀ náà, ó sì ń fún àwọn ọmọ ìjọ ní Ara jẹ àti ẹ̀jẹ̀ mu bí ó ti máa ń ṣe.

translation.en: Alarms were raised when the official website of the Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese published a translated article by Russian website Pravoslavie.ru (meaning "Orthodox Christianity") claiming it's "impossible for believers to be infected during church rituals".
translation.yo: Ìròyìn kàn nígbà tí ojúlé ibùdó ìtakùn Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese ṣe àtẹ̀jáde ògbufọ̀ article àrọko ibùdó ìtakùn tó jẹ́ ti Russia ìyẹn Pravoslavie.ru (ìtumọ̀ "Ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ Àtijọ́ ") tó ń sọ wí pé "kò lè ṣe é ṣe kí àwọn onígbàgbọ́ ó k'árùn láti ara ìlànà-ìsìn ìjọ".

translation.en: The text is signed by Russian priest Sergey Adonin, who claims to have knowledge of microbiology and experience working in hospitals.
translation.yo: Àlùfáà Sergey Adonin ti Russia ló buwọ́ lu àpilẹ̀kọ náà, ẹni tó sọ pé òun ní ìmọ̀ nípa ìṣẹ̀dá ẹ̀dá oníyè àìfojúrí pẹ̀lú ìrírí iṣẹ́ ní iléèwòsàn.

translation.en: He stressed in the article that the rule of using the same spoon instituted in the 7th century Bizantium has so far done no harm, because "faith in God protects both the parishioners and the priests".
translation.yo: Ó sọ síwájú sí i nínú àpilẹ̀kọ náà wí pé lílo ṣíbí kan náà bí wọn ti ṣe fi lọ́lẹ̀ ní ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún kéje ayé Bizantium ò fa ìpalára, nítorí "ìgbàgbọ́ nínú Ọlọ́run ń fi ìṣọ́ ààbò bo àlùfáà àti ọmọ ìjọ".

translation.en: Also in North Macedonia, right-wing propagandists expressed support to the church.
translation.yo: Ní North Macedonia, àwọn tí ó ń mú ṣe ti ìlànà-ìsìn náà ní kò sí aburú nínú ìlànà iléèjọsìn náà.

translation.en: For instance, one conservative TV host — who in the past promoted anti-vax activists — boasted on Twitter to have participated in risky religious rituals:
translation.yo: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, atọ́kùn ètò lórí ẹ̀rọ amóhùnmáwòrán tó jẹ́ adàṣà-àtijọ́-mú-ṣinṣin — ajìjàǹgbara ẹni tó ti fi ìgbà kan rí ṣe ìpolongo ìtako ìbupá — fúnnu lórí Twitter wí pé òun ti kópa nínú àwọn ìlànà-ìsìn ajẹmẹ́sìn tó léwu:

translation.en: Tweet: I received Holy Communion last Sunday in the Church of Holy Annunciation which is part of the Clinical Center in Skopje and will do it again!
translation.yo: Túwíìtì: Mo jẹ Ara Olúwa mu ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa lọ́jọ́ Àìkú tó kọjá nínú Iléèjọsìn Holy Annunciation tí ó wà nínú Iléèwòsàn ti Skopje tí n ó sì tún ṣe é!

translation.en: What's your problem?
translation.yo: Kí ni ìṣòro rẹ̀?

translation.en: Link title: In spite of the appeal by health authorities: Believers received Holy Communion without fear from the coronavirus.
translation.yo: Àkọlé adarí: Pẹ̀lú gbogbo ẹ̀bẹ̀ àjọ tó ń rí sí ètò ìlera: Àwọn onígbàgbọ́ jẹ Ara mu ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa láì fòyà fún ààrùn coronavirus.

translation.en: Sladjana Velkov, an anti-vax celebrity operating in Serbia and North Macedonia, recently declared that the situation is "not serious" and that the new virus is "just a common cold which, like the other common colds, affects only older people or people with compromised immunity".
translation.yo: Sladjana Velkov, ẹni tó gbajúmọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí alátakò-ìbupá tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní Serbia àti Àríwá Macedonia, sọ láì pẹ́ yìí wí pé nǹkan kò "le tóyẹn" àti pé "ọ̀fìnkìn lásán ni, èyí tí kò yàtọ̀ sí ọ̀fìnkìn tí a ti mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀, tó máa ń ṣe àwọn àgbàlagbà tàbí àwọn tí ìlera ara wọn kò pé tó".

translation.en: Meanwhile from Italy, where over 631 people have died from the infection and more than 10,000 are affected, this user tweeted:
translation.yo: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè Italy, níbi tí 631 ẹ̀mí èèyàn 631 ti bọ́ tí àwọn tí ó tó 10,000 ti lùgbàdì àrùn náà, aṣàmúlò kan túwíìtì:

translation.en: So far there have been seven confirmed cases of COVID-19 in North Macedonia; 25 in Slovenia; 13 in Croatia; six in Albania; five in Serbia; five in Bosnia; and zero in Montenegro.
translation.yo: Bí á bá kà á ní méníméjì, ó ti tó ẹni méje tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19 ní North Macedonia; 25 ní Slovenia; 13 ní Croatia; mẹ́fà ní Albania; fi márùn-ún ní Serbia; márùn-ún ní Bosnia; òdo ní Montenegro.

translation.en: There have been 28 cases in Romania and six in Bulgaria.
translation.yo: Ó ti tó ẹni 28 tó ti kó o ní Romania, mẹ́fà ní Bulgaria.

translation.en: Christians elsewhere
translation.yo: Onígbàgbọ́ níbi gbogbo

translation.en: The world has already witnessed how the novel coronavirus can spread through religious congregations.
translation.yo: Ilé ayé ti rí bí coronavirus àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀ ṣe lè ràn níbi ìpéjọ ajẹmẹ́sìn.

translation.en: Last month, a majority of 7,400 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in South Korea — a country that until then seemed to have the outbreak under control — were traced to the group Shincheonji Church of Jesus.
translation.yo: Lóṣù tó kọjá, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó tó 7,400 ni a gbọ́ wí pé ó ti ní àrùn apànìyàn COVID-19 ní South Korea — orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó jọ pé ó ti ń gbá àrùn náà mọ́lẹ̀ — rí àrùn náà lára Iléèjọsìn ẹgbẹ́ Shincheonji ti Jésù.

translation.en: Criminal charges were filed against the sect — often called a cult — and its 88-year-old leader publicly apologized.
translation.yo: A fi ẹ̀sùn ọ̀daràn kan ẹgbẹ́ náà — tí wọ́n máa ń pè ní igbẹ́-ìmùlẹ̀ — olórí ẹgbẹ́ náà tí í ṣe ẹni 8-ọdún wá síta láti ṣe ìtọrọ àforíjì.

translation.en: Meanwhile, the Orthodox Diocese of Korea announced changes in its liturgical practices in accordance with the recommendations of the Ministry of Health:
translation.yo: Ní tirẹ̀, Àjọ Ìlànà-ìsìn Àtijọ́ ti Korea ṣe ìfilọ̀ nípa àwọn àyípadà tó dé bá ìsìn rẹ̀ ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àfilélẹ̀ Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Ìlera:

translation.en: 1. During the Divine Liturgy all believers will wear masks.
translation.yo: 1. Gbogbo onígbàgbọ́ yóò wọ ìbomúbẹnu lásìkò tí ìsìn bá ń lọ lọ́wọ́.

translation.en: 2. Before entering the Church, they will disinfect their hands with a disinfectant present at the entrance of the Church.
translation.yo: 2. Kí wọ́n ó wọ Iléèjọsìn, wọ́n yóò fi apakòkòrò tó wà lẹ́nu àbáwọlé Iléèjọsìn ra ọwọ́ wọn.

translation.en: 3. They will not shake hands with anyone.
translation.yo: 3. Wọn kò ní gba ẹnìkan lọ́wọ́.

translation.en: 4. They will not kiss the hand of the Clergy.
translation.yo: 4. Wọn kò ní f'ẹnu ko Àlùfáà ìjọ lọ́wọ́.

translation.en: 5. They will not kiss the Icons, but they will bow before them.
translation.yo: 5. Wọn kò ní fẹnu ko àwọn Ère, àmọ́ wọn ó tẹríba níwájú wọn.

translation.en: 6. They will not use the liturgical books at the time of prayer.
translation.yo: 6. Wọn kò ní lo àwọn ìwé àdúrà nígbà ìsìn.

translation.en: 7. They will not receive the Antidoron from the Clergy, but on their own as they leave the church.
translation.yo: 7. Wọn kò ní gba Àkàrà lọ́wọ́ Àlùfáà ìjọ, àmọ́ fúnra wọn bí wọ́n bá ń jáde kúrò nínú iléèjọsìn.

translation.en: 8. The Agape Meal will not be served following the Sunday Liturgy.
translation.yo: 8. Oúnjẹ Àpèjẹ Ifẹ̀ kò ní jẹ́ pínpín lọ́jọ́ Àìkú.

translation.en: 9. The various group meetings of the Faithful as well as the Catechumens will not take place.
translation.yo: 9. Àwọn ìpàdé ẹlẹ́gbẹ́jẹgbẹ́ àti ti àwọn tó ń kọ́ ìsìn Ọlọ́run kò ní wáyé.

translation.en: Some churches in Europe have adopted similar measures, such as the Catholic church in Italy.
translation.yo: Àwọn ilé ìjọsìn kan ní Ilẹ̀ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti ń ṣe àyípadà sí ìlànà ìsìn wọn, bí i ìjọ Àgùdà ti Italy.

translation.en: The diocese in Croatia have also enacted restrictive rules and, in France, a pilgrimage site in the city of Lourdes has been shut down.
translation.yo: Àjọ ẹ̀sìn ìgbàgbọ́ Croatia náà en ti ṣ'òfin tó dá lé àrùn náà, ní France, ibi ìrìnàjò mímọ kan ní ìlú Lourdes ti di títì pa.

translation.en: The Orthodox Church of Romania issued a decree announcing "exceptional measures taken only because of the threat of an epidemic":
translation.yo: Iléèjọsìn Ìlànà-ìsìn Àtijọ́ ti Romania fi òfin kan síta "tó jẹ́ àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tí ènìyàn yóò tẹ̀lé bí àjàkálẹ̀ bá dúkokò":

translation.en: Believers who are afraid of virus transmission may temporarily refrain from kissing the holy icons in the churches.
translation.yo: Àwọn onígbàgbọ́ tíbẹ̀rùbojo àrùn apànìyàn náà ti sojo s'ọ́kan wọn yóò pa ìfènuko àwọn ère inú ilé ìjọsìn lára.

translation.en: They can exceptionally ask the priest to use their own spoon for the Holy Communion.
translation.yo: Bí ó bá wù wọ́n, wọ́n leè sọ fún àlùfáà wí pé ṣíbí ti wọn ni àwọn fẹ́ lò fi gba Ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa mu.

translation.en: After Italy enacted a complete lockdown on national territory, other European states, like the Czech Republic also took more drastic measures on March 10, such as the closure of schools.
translation.yo: Lẹ́yìn tí Italy pàṣẹ pé kí gbogbo orígun mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin ìlú ó di sísé pa, àwọn alámùúlégbè, bí i Ilẹ̀ Olómìnira Czech náà gbé àwọn àgbékalẹ̀ kan lọ́jọ́ 10, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà tí wọ́n ṣán àwọniiléèwé pa.

translation.en: The Government of North Macedonia declared a state of emergency and also shut down kindergardens, schools, and universities for two weeks.
translation.yo: Ìjọba North Macedonia kéde ipò ìlú ò f'ara rọ, ó sì ti àwọn jẹ́léósinmi, iléèwé, títí kan iléèwé gíga jù lọ Ifásitìi pa fún ọ̀sẹ̀ méjì.

translation.en: Check out Global Voices’ special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19.
translation.yo: Check Yẹ àwọn iṣẹ́ àkànṣe Ohùn Àgbáyé lórí arapa COVID-19 lágbàáyé.

translation.en: Nigeria enforces travel bans amid sloppy management of COVID-19 cases
translation.yo: Orílẹ̀-Èdè Nàìjíríà fi òfin de ìrìn-àjò lójúnà ìṣàmójútó àwọn tó ti kó kòkòrò àìfojúrí COVID 19

translation.en: Travel ban on 13 countries with over 1,000 cases of COVID-19
translation.yo: Ìfòfindèrìnàjò àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè 13 tí ènìyàn tó ti kó COVID-19 ju 1,000 lọ

translation.en: Image by Pete Linforth from Pixabay. Used under a Pixabay license, public use.
translation.yo: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Pete Linforth ní Pixabay. Ìlò àwòrán pẹ̀lú àṣẹ Pixabay, fún ìlò gbogboògbò.

translation.en: Check out Global Voices’ special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19.
translation.yo: Yẹ àkọsílẹ̀ àkànṣe Global Voices wò lórí ipa COVID-19 lágbàáyé.

translation.en: Nigeria has confirmed five new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total number of coronavirus patients to eight,  according to the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àjò tí ó ń kápá ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn ní Nàìjíríà ṣe sọ, àwọn èèyàn márùn-ún mìíràn ni wọ́n ti fìdí rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé wọ́n ti kó kòkòro àrùn COVID-19, àròpọ̀ iye àwọn tí wọ́n ní àrùn náà ní Nàìjíríà wá jẹ́ mẹ́jọ.

translation.en: The increase to eight patients came just 48 hours after Dr. E. Osagie Ehanire confirmed the third case of COVID-19, March 16, as a "Nigerian national in her 30s who returned from a short visit to the United Kingdom on March 13":
translation.yo: Iye àwọn ẹni tí ó ní kòkòrò àrùn náà di mẹ́jọ ní ọjọ́ méjì lẹ́yìn tí dókítà E. Osagie Ehanire fìdí i rẹ múlẹ̀ ní ọjọ́ 16, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na pé wọ́n ti rí ẹni kẹ́ta tí ó kó kòkòrò àìfojúrí COVID-19, ìyen "ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà kan tí ó lé ní ẹni ọgbọ̀n tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ dé láti United Kingdom ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na".

translation.en: The patient voluntarily began a 14-day self-isolation in Lagos, during which she developed symptoms of fever and cough.
translation.yo: Aláìsàn náà ya ara rẹ̀ sọ́tọ̀ fún ọjọ́ 14 ní ìlú Èkó, láàárín àsìkò yìí ni ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ní àmì àìsàn ibà àti ikọ̀.

translation.en: The patient is currently admitted to the Infectious Disease Hospital, Yaba, Lagos.
translation.yo: Aláìsàn náà wà ní ilé ìwòsàn tí wọ́n ti ń ṣètọ́jú Kòkòro àkóràn ní Yaba, ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.

translation.en: She is clinically stable and responding to treatment.
translation.yo: Ara rẹ̀ ti ń balẹ̀, ó sì ń dáhùn sí ìtọ́jú dáadáa.

translation.en: As numbers of COVID-19 cases continue to rise in Nigeria, the government has yielded to public outcry on March 18 by placing travel restrictions on citizens from 13 countries with over 1,000 domestic cases of coronavirus: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, the United States, the United Kingdom, Netherlands and Switzerland.
translation.yo: Bí í iye àwọn ènìyàn tí ó kó kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ṣe ń pọ̀ sí i ni Nàìjíríà, ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti gbọ́ ohun tí àwọn aráàlú sọ ní ọjọ́ 18, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na nípa fífi òfin de àwọn tí ó ń rin ìrìn àjò láti orílẹ̀ èdè 13 bí i: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, United States, United Kingdom, Netherlands àti Switzerland tí ó ní ju ènìyàn 1000 lọ tí ó ti kó kòkòrò àrùn Kòrónà láti má wọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: Those who have already entered the country from these countries must go through a 14-day quarantine.
translation.yo: Àwọn tí wọ́n ti wọ Nàìjíríà tẹ́lẹ̀ láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí a dárúkọ yìí gbọ́dọ̀ ya ara wọn sọ́tọ̀ fún ọjọ́ 14.

translation.en: On February 27, an Italian national visiting Nigeria was confirmed as the index case for COVID-19 in the country.
translation.yo: Ọjọ́ 27 ni oṣù Èrèlé ní a fìdí rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè Italy kan tí ó rìn ìrìnàjò wá sí orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà jẹ́ ẹni àkọ́kọ́ tí ó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19.

translation.en: Read more: An Italian national is the index case of COVID-19 disease in Nigeria
translation.yo: Kà sí i: Ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè Italy kan tí ó rìn ìrìnàjò wá sí orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà ni ó kọ́kọ́ ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19

translation.en: The second confirmed case, according to the NCDC, is a contact of the index case who has now tested negative twice.
translation.yo: Ẹni kejì tí a fìdí rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé ó ní kòkòrò àrùn yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bí NCDC ṣe sọ jẹ́ ẹni tí ó rìnnà pàdé ẹni àkọ́kọ́ tí ó kó àrùn náà, tí ara rẹ̀ sì ti yá báyìí lẹ́yìn tí àyẹ̀wò méjì ti fi hàn pé àyẹ̀wò náà kò sí lára rẹ̀ mọ́.

translation.en: Consequently, the second case was cleared of the virus and was discharged to go home on 13th of March 2020, states the NCDC.
translation.yo: Ẹnìkejì yìí ò ní àrùn náà mọ́, wọ́n sì ti fi í sílẹ̀ kí ó máa lọ sílé ní ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, ọdún 2020, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi àjọ NCDC ṣe sọ.

translation.en: Many Nigerian netizens have not been satisfied with the current response to COVID-19 and have called for tougher measures to prevent the spread of the pandemic in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Bí wọ́n ṣe ń bójú tó àrùn COVID-19 kò tẹ́ ọ̀pọ̀ aráàlú lórí ayélujára lọ́rùn, wón sì ti ń béèrè fún àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó lágbára láti dẹ́kun ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn náà ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: Netizen Ayobami decried the slow response of the NCDC. He advised the agency to "stop the media parade and do some work!"
translation.yo: Ọmọ ìlú lórí ayélujára, Ayobami kéde pé ìgbésẹ̀ NCDC falẹ̀. Ó gbà wọ́n nímọ̀ràn pé "kí wọ́n dẹ́kun ṣíṣe àṣehàn lórí ayélujára kí wọ́n sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́!"

translation.en: Gideon says it "should scare all of us" that COVID-19 testing is slow in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Gideon sọ pé "ó yẹ kí ó bà wá lẹ́rù" pé ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wò fún kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ń falẹ̀ ní Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: "Restrict travelers coming in especially from countries" affected by this virus, insists journalist Bayo Olupohunda:
translation.yo: "Ẹ fi òfin de àwọn arìnrìn-àjò tí ó fẹ́ wọlé láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè mìíràn" pàápàá jù lọ àwọn tí ó wá láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí àrùn náà ti gbilẹ̀, akọ̀ròyìn Bayo Olupohunda náà tẹnumọ:

translation.en: Dr. Whitewalker insists that a travel ban is a normal epidemiological intervention in order to stem the tide of transmission during a pandemic like this:
translation.yo: Dr. Whitewalker náà tẹnpẹlẹ mọ́ ọn pé kò sí ohun tí ó burú nínú fífi òfin de àwọn arìnrìn-àjò ní àkókò tí wọ́n ṣiṣẹ́ ìṣàdínkù ìtànkálẹ́ àrùn láti lè dẹ́kun àkóràn ní àsìkò ìtànkálẹ́ àrùn bí i irú èyí.

translation.en: Dr. Chikwe Ihekweazu, head of NCDC, pleaded that they are "trying VERY hard to meet all urgent needs":
translation.yo: Dr. Chikwe Ihekweazu, olórí àjọ NCDC, bẹ̀bẹ̀ pé àwọn ń "gbìyànjú GIDI láti rí i pé àwọn ṣe gbogbo ohun tí ó yẹ kí àwọn ṣe":

translation.en: On March 17, the Senate, Nigeria's upper legislative house, initially called for a ban on flights from coronavirus high-risk countries like the United Kingdom and China, before extending the restrictions the following day.
translation.yo: Ní ọjọ́ 17 oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà ti kọ́kọ́ sọ pé kí wọ́n fi òfin de àwọn ọkọ̀ òfurufú tí ó ń bọ̀ láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí àrùn náà ti gbilẹ̀ bí i United Kingdom àti China, kí wọ́n tó dúró di ọjọ́ kejì kí wọ́n tó fi òfin náà múlẹ̀.

translation.en: All visitors from affected countries will undergo a "supervised self-isolation and testing for 14 days," reports the Cable Nigeria.
translation.yo: Cable Nigeria jábọ̀ gbogbo àwọn tí wọ́n wá láti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí àrùn náà ti gbilẹ̀ ni wọ́n máa yà sọ́tọ̀ pẹ̀lú àbójútó fún ọjọ́ mẹ́rìnlá.

translation.en: The government also temporarily suspended visas-on-arrival in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Ìjọba àpapọ̀ sì fi òfin de fífún àwọn ènìyàn ní visa Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: The travel ban comes into effect on Saturday, March 21, 2020, and will last four weeks, which is open to a possible extension upon review.
translation.yo: Ìfòfindèrìnàjò náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní àbámẹ́ta ọjọ́ 21, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún 2020, yóò sì wà fún ọ̀sẹ̣̀ mẹ́rin tí ó ṣe é ṣe kí wọ́n sún un síwájú lẹ́yìn àpérò.

translation.en: Read more: COVID-19 in Africa: ‘Unprecedented levels of mobilization’ as nations brace for pandemic
translation.yo: Kà sí i: COVID-19 ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀: ‘Ìgbáradì tí a kò rí irú rẹ̀ rí’ bí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ṣe ń múra sílẹ̀ fún ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn

translation.en: Several African countries have been implementing tough protocols to mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
translation.yo: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ti ń gbé ìgbésẹ̀ láti ṣe àdínkù ìtànkálẹ̀ kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19.

translation.en: These stringent measures include placing travel restrictions on nations with high numbers of COVID-19 cases.
translation.yo: Lára àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ yìí ni fífi òfin de ìrìn-àjò láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 náà ti gbilẹ̀ láti má ṣe wọ orílẹ̀ èdè wọn.

translation.en: Sloppy management
translation.yo: Ìṣàmójútó tí kò péye tó

translation.en: There are reports about the inadequate and slipshod response by health officials to the COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria.
translation.yo: Àwọn ìjábọ̀ kan wà nípa bí ìṣàmójútó àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ elétò ìlera kò ṣe péye tó lórí àwọn tó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ni orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: A 70-year-old woman who had spent five months in the United Kingdom returned to Nigeria, on March 11.
translation.yo: Obìnrin kan tí ó jẹ́ ẹni ọdún 70 tí ó ti lo oṣù márùn-ún ní United Kingdom padà sí Nàìjíríà ní ọjọ́ 11 oṣù Ẹrẹ́na.

translation.en: Soon after, she presented with COVID-19 symptoms like cold and excessive mucous and on March 13, she was rushed to Enugu State Teaching Hospital (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, in southeast Nigeria.
translation.yo: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà díẹ̀ tí ó dé, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní àmì àìsàn kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 bí i òtútù àti ikun tí ó pọ̀ lápọ̀jù ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, wọ́n sì sáré gbé lọ sí Teaching Hospital ti ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, ní gúúsù ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: She was isolated in ESUTH Colliery Parklane while her samples were sent to NCDC for diagnosis on March 14.
translation.yo: Wọ́n yà á sọ́tọ̀ ní ESUTH Colliery Parklane, wọ́n sì fi àyẹ̀wọ̀ tí wọ́n ṣe fun un ṣọwọ́ sí àjọ NCDC ní ọjọ́ 14, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na fún àyẹ̀wò.

translation.en: On March 15, the woman died after the NCDC had reported that she tested negative to COVID-19.
translation.yo: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, obìnrin náà kú lẹ́yìn tí àjọ NCDC jábọ̀ pé kò ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19.

translation.en: However, in a letter written to Enugu's state governor, the woman's daughter alleged that her mother was "stigmatized" by the hospital staff who placed her in a “dilapidated” isolation centre overgrown with “grass and debris”.
translation.yo: Bẹ́ẹ̀, nínú lẹ́tà tí wọ́n kọ sí gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu, ọmọ obìnrin náà fẹ̀sùn kan àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ilé ìwòsàn náà pé "tàbùkù" ìyá òun, wọ́n gbé e sínú "ilé àkọ́kù" tí ó kún fún koríko.

translation.en: Another ill-managed COVID-19 case presented in Lagos, the commercial capital of Nigeria.
translation.yo: Ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnìkan tí ó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 tí wọn kò ṣe àbójútó tó péye fún wáyé ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó tí ó jẹ́ olú-ìlú ìdókòòwò ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

translation.en: On March 17, David Hundeyin, a journalist with News Wire, reported the poor handling of a suspected COVID-19 case at Dangote Oil Refinery Company in Ibeju-Lekki, Lagos, which has precipitated panic among workers.
translation.yo: Ní ọjọ́ 17, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, David Hundeyin tí ó jẹ́ akọ̀ròyìn pẹ̀lú News Wire, jábọ̀ nípa ìṣàmójútó tí kò gúnrégé tó lórí ọ̀rọ̀ ẹni tí wọ́n furasí pé ó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ní ilé iṣẹ́ Dangote ní Ibeju-Lekki, ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó, tí ó sì ti ń fa ìpayà láàárín àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ibẹ̀.

translation.en: On March 12, an Indian pipefitter from Dangote Refinery flew into Nigeria from Mumbai, after a brief stopover in Cairo, Egypt.
translation.yo: Ní ọjọ́ kejìlá oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, òṣìṣẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ Dangote kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ India tí ó ń tún ọ̀pá omi ṣe wá sí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà láti Mumbai, lẹ́yìn tí ó dúró díẹ̀ ní Cairo, ní orílẹ̀-èdè Egypt.

translation.en: Hudeyin's investigation revealed that the pipefitter developed "a fever, a dry cough, a sore throat and significant breathing difficulty," a day after his return from India.
translation.yo: Ìwádìí Hudeyin fi hàn pé ọkùnrin náà tí ó ń tún ọ̀pá omi ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ní "ibà, ikọ́ gbígbẹ, ọ̀fun dídùn àti àìlè mí délẹ̀ ", ní ọjọ́ kejì tí ó dé láti India.

translation.en: Yet, “it is unclear whether anyone at Dangote Refinery attempted to establish contact” with appropriate health officials.
translation.yo: Síbẹ̀, "kò tí ì hàn bóyá ẹnikẹ́ni ní iléeṣẹ́ Dangote ti gbìyànjú láti kàn sí" àwọn elétò ìlera tí ọ̀rọ̀ náà kàn.

translation.en: Hudeyin further lamented that the firm took advantage of "the lax regulatory environment" in Nigeria "to put its own interests first", which puts the life of staff as well as the general public at risk.
translation.yo: Hudeyin sọ̀rọ̀ síwájú pé ilé iṣẹ́ náà ń lo àǹfààní "àyíká òfin tí kò múnádóko tó" ní Nàìjíríà "láti fi èrè tirẹ̀ síwájú", èyí sì ń fi ẹ̀mí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ rẹ̀ àti gbogbo àwùjọ sínú ewu.

translation.en: This report forced refinery management to release a report stating that the said patient has been moved to the Infectious Disease Hospital in Yaba, Lagos.
translation.yo: Ìròyìn yìí mú kí iléeṣẹ́ náà gbé èrò wọn jáde pé àwọn ti gbé aláìsàn náà lọ sí ilé ìwòsàn tí wọ́n ti ń ṣètọ́jú kòkòrò Àkóràn ní Yaba, ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.

translation.en: How is COVID-19 reshaping the political and global future of China?
translation.yo: Ọ̀nà wo ni àrùn COVID-19 ń gbà ṣe àtúnṣe sí ètò ìṣèlú àti ẹ̀yìn-ọ̀la Orílẹ̀-èdè China lágbàáyé?

translation.en: Poster displaying a map of China on the four characters reading 武汉肺炎 meaning "Wuhan pneumonia" (which is still used in Chinese), as the epidemic was initially known, before it was given the name of COVID-19.
translation.yo: Àwòrán tó ń fi ààlà-ilẹ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè China hàn lórí ọmọ ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́rin tí kíkà rẹ̀ jẹ́ 武汉肺炎 tí ó túmọ̀ sí "àrùn ẹ̀dọ̀fóró Wuhan" (tí ó ṣì jẹ́ lílo ní èdè Chinese), gẹ́gẹ́ bí a ti ṣe mọ àjàkálẹ̀ náà ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, kí ó tó yí orúkọ padà sí COVID-19.

translation.en: Image used with permission.
translation.yo: A gba àṣẹ láti lo àwòrán.

translation.en: What started at a seafood market as a local health issue has grown into a national health crisis in China.
translation.yo: Ohun tí ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ nínú ọjà oúnjẹ inú odò, gẹ́gẹ́ bí i ọ̀ràn àìlera ìbílẹ̀, ti wá di nǹkan tó rànká Orílẹ̀-èdè China.

translation.en: After the Wuhan coronavirus was identified in December 2019, a chain reaction was set in motion that has profoundly shaken Chinese society and challenged Beijing’s political stability.
translation.yo: Lẹ́yìn ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ìjẹyọ kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ní Wuhan nínú Oṣù Kejìlá Ọdún 2019, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ló ṣẹ̀ ní ṣísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé ló ṣú yọ tó sì fi àwùjọ ilẹ̀ Chinese làkàlàkà tí ó sì tún dojú ìpèníjà kọ ìdúróṣinṣin ètò ìṣèlú Beijing.

translation.en: Gripped by its obsession with information control, the Chinese government, both local and central, delayed the release of life-saving information for weeks.
translation.yo: Kíkúndùn ìṣàkóso ìròyìn ti fún ìjọba lọ́rùn, àti ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ àti ìjọba àpapọ̀ ní àárín gbùngbùn, ló máa ń fa ìdádúró fún àgbéjáde ìròyìn tí yóò ṣe ará ìlú láǹfààní fún ọ̀sẹ̀ pípẹ́.

translation.en: When they suddenly announced drastic measures to prevent the spread of the epidemic in late January, for many it was much too late as the Chinese New Year kick-off celebrations had already begun.
translation.yo: Nígbà tí wọ́n wá sọ jí láti ṣe ìkéde lórí àwọn ọ̀nà tí yóò dẹ́kun ìtànká àjàkálẹ̀ náà, ó ti bọ́ sórí, nítorí ayẹyẹ ọdún tuntun ìran Chinese ọlọ́dọọdún ti gbérasọ.

translation.en: Doctors and scientists are still researching and debating the possible origin of the previously unknown Wuhan coronavirus, which causes COVID-2019, a respiratory virus that infects the lungs and can lead to pneumonia.
translation.yo: Àwọn Dókítà àti àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ sì ń ṣe ìwádìí àti ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro-ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ohun tí ó lè jẹ́ orísun àrùn tí wọ́n mọ̀ nígbà náà lọ́hùn-ún gẹ́gẹ́ bí kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ti Wuhan, tí ó padà wá ṣe okùnfà COVID-19, kòkòrò àìfojúrí tó ń mú kí ènìyàn má leè mí sókèsódò tí ó sì ń fa àrùn ẹ̀dọ̀fóró.

translation.en: One possible theory is that it comes from snakes or bats that are consumed as a delicacy in China and were sold at the Huanan wet market in Wuhan where the virus is believed to originate.
translation.yo: Ìdámọ̀ràn ohun tí ó lè fa sábàbí àrùn náà kan fi yé wí pé kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà jẹ yọ látàrí ẹran ejò tàbí ẹran àdán tí àwọn ará China máa ń jẹ l'óúnjẹ, tí wọ́n ń tà ní ọjà Huanan wet ní agbègbè Wuhan níbi tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ní èrò wí pé ibẹ̀ ni orísun kòkòrò àìfojúrí yìí.

translation.en: One of the key questions determining the spread of the virus is its transmissibility: whether it can jump from human to human, and how many people can be infected on average by the same virus carrier.
translation.yo: Ìbéèrè kan tí ó nílò ìdáhùn ni ti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn yìí: bóyá ó leè rànká láti ara èèyàn kan sí ìkejì, àti ìyè èèyàn mélòó ló leè kó àìsàn yìí látara ẹni tí ó bá ti ní i.

translation.en: The latest medical evidence indicates there is human-to-human transmission, and what is concerning is that it seems to happen before the virus carrier develops symptoms, thus making detection incredibly challenging.
translation.yo: Ẹ̀rí láti ìmọ̀ ìlera tó fẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ṣe ìṣípayá àrànkán láti ara ènìyàn kan sí ìkejì, tí ó fi jẹ́ wí pé kòkòrò náà yóò ti wà lágọ̀ọ́ ara fún ìgbà díẹ̀ kí ẹni tí ó kó o ó tó máa rí àwọn ààmì rẹ̀ lára, tí èyí ò sì mú mímọ ẹni tí ó bá ti lu gúdẹ àrùn náà rọrùn.

translation.en: As for the rate of transmission, called “basic reproduction number” by epidemiologists, it is believed to be between 2 to 3 in late January, meaning one person infects two to three persons, but the numbers are still being discussed and require further research should proper data be made available.
translation.yo: Ní ti bí àrùn náà ti ń ràn, èyí tí àwọn onímọ̀ nípa àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn ń pè ní “òǹkà ìpìlẹ̀ ìbísí“, gbà pé ó wà láàárín 2 sí 3 ní ìparí Oṣù Kìn-ín-ní, ẹni tí ó ní i yóò kó o ran ẹni méjì sí mẹ́ta, ṣùgbọ́n ìfikùnlukùn àti ìwádìí kò dúró, ìyẹn bí àwọn ìwífún-alálàyè tí ó wúlò bá wà ní àrọ́wọ́tó.

translation.en: As the figure of infected people rises daily, a major health crisis has developed in China’s central province of Hubei and its capital Wuhan that have a combined population of nearly 60 million people.
translation.yo: Bí òǹkà àwọn tí wọ́n ti ní kòkòrò yìí ṣe ń lọ sókè sí i lójoojúmó, àáríngbùngbùn Orílẹ̀-èdè China tí i ṣe Hubei àti Olú-ìlú rẹ̀ tí í ṣe Wuhan ti ní ìdojúkọ tó gogò lórí ètò ìlera, tí àpapọ̀ àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbé lágbègbè yìí sì jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ́rùn ní ìlọ́po 60.

translation.en: As cases have been confirmed all over China, all medical staff are on alert, adding pressure on a medical system that is often insufficient for such a large and aging population.
translation.yo: Bí iye àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn yìí ṣe ń pọ̀ káàkiri Orílẹ̀-èdè China, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ elétò ìlera ti wà digbí, tí wọ́n sì tún kóná mọ́ ètò ìlera tí kò sùwábọ̀ tó fún ìtọ́jú àwọn ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye arúgbó tó kún ìlú.

translation.en: But the Wuhan coronavirus is not just a health crisis, it is also a major political moment of truth.
translation.yo: Ṣùgbọ́n àrùn kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà Wuhan náà kì í ṣe ìkọlù ètò ìlera lásán, ó jẹ́ àkókò òtítọ́ ètò ìṣèlú tí ó lákaakì.

translation.en: Trust in the government that claimed there was nothing to worry about until very late in the game has eroded public confidence significantly, and not just in Hubei province.
translation.yo: Ìgbẹ́kẹ̀lé ìjọba tí ó sọ fún àwọn ará ìlú wí pé kò s'éwu l'óko àfi gìrì àparò ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, títí tí ẹ̀pa ò fi bóró mọ́, tí àwọn ará ìlú kò sì ní ìfọkàntán nínú àwọn ìjọba wọn mọ́, àti pé, kì í ṣe ní agbègbè Hubei nìkan ni èyí ti ṣẹlẹ̀.

translation.en: Beijing was criticized for the way it mishandled the SARS crisis in 2002-2003 as it concealed information from the World Health Organization (WHO).
translation.yo: Àwọn ará ìlú bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ìjọba Beijing fún ọwọ́ yẹpẹrẹ tí wọ́n fi mú ọ̀rọ̀ àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn èémí SARS tó ṣú yọ ní ọdún 2002 sí 2003, bí ó ti ṣe fi ìròyìn tó péye lórí rẹ̀ pamọ́ fún Àjọ Elétò Ìlara Lágbàáyé (WHO).

translation.en: China’s top leader Xi Jinping kept silent on the recent outbreak until January 20 when he recognized the severity of the situation in a public statement – over one month after the first cases had been identified.
translation.yo: Olórí Orílẹ̀-èdè China àgbà Xi Jinping dákẹ́ rọrọ lórí àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn yìí àyàfi ìgbà tí ó di ọjọ́ 20, Oṣù Kìn-ín-ní Ọdún, tí ó kéde fún ará ìlú lẹ́yìn oṣù kan tí àrùn náà ti ń ṣọṣẹ́, pé ọ̀ràn náà ti kọjá àfẹnusọ.

translation.en: Control of information remains tight, and as China is experiencing a trade war with the US and an economic slowdown, the handling of the Wuhan coronavirus crisis will determine the course of Chinese society and politics in 2020.
translation.yo: Agbára lórí ìṣàkóso àtẹ̀jáde ìròyìn fẹsẹ̀ múlẹ̀ rìnrìn ní orílẹ̀-èdè China, àti pé, ìwọ̀yáàjà ètò káràkátà pẹ̀lú Orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà, àti bí ọrọ̀-ajé wọn ṣe ń dẹnukọlẹ̀, bí wọ́n bá ṣe yanjú ìṣòro kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ti Wuhan náà ni yóò forí lé ní ọdún 2020.

translation.en: Mozambique and Cape Verde's telcos offer affordable mobile internet as citizens urged to stay home
translation.yo: Àwọn Ilé Iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ní Mozambique àti Cape Verde tẹ́ pẹpẹ ètò ẹ̀dínwó fún ayélujára lórí ẹ̀rọ alágbèéká láti mú kí àwọn ọmọ-ìlú ó dúró sílé

translation.en: Santa Maria Avenue, Cape Verde. Photo by Miccaela, Wikimedia Commons. CC-BY 3.0
translation.yo: Ojú ọ̀nà Santa Maria, Cape Verde. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Miccaela, Wikimedia Commons. CC-BY 3.0

translation.en: Check out Global Voices’ special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19.
translation.yo: Yẹ àkànṣe iṣẹ́ tí Ohùn Àgbáyé’ ti ṣe lórí ipa tí kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà COVID-19 ń kó lágbàáyé

translation.en: As more and more Africans are ordered to stay at home amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Mozambique and Cape Verde state-owned telcos are offering significant discounts on mobile data.
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àṣẹ kónílégbélé ṣe ń múlẹ̀ ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ látàrí àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn COVID-19, àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ti Ìpínlẹ̀ ní Orílẹ̀-èdè Mozambique àti Cape Verde ń fún àwọn ará ìlú ní ẹ̀dínwó lórí owó-ìlò-ayélujára ní orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèéká.

translation.en: To date, Mozambique has registered a total of 10 confirmed cases of COVID-19 and no deaths, while Cape Verde has had six cases and one death.
translation.yo: Di àsìkò yìí, Orílẹ̀-èdè Mozambique ti ní àkọsílẹ̀ ènìyàn 10 tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19, ṣùgbọ́n tí kò tí ì sí ẹni tí ó ti bá àìsàn náà lọ, àmọ́ ẹni 6 ló ti kó àrùn náà ní Cape Verde tí ẹnìkan sì ti di ẹni ẹbọra ń bá jẹun.

translation.en: Last week, both countries have imposed a 30-day state of emergency, with the possibility of extension.
translation.yo: Ní ọ̀sẹ̀ tí ó kọjá, Orílẹ̀-èdè méjèèjì ti pàṣẹ òfin pàjáwìrì ìlú-ò-f'ara-rọ olóṣù kan látàrí àjàkálẹ̀ àìsàn tó gbayé kan, ó sì ṣe é ṣe kí wọ́n ṣe àfikún-un rẹ̀.

translation.en: According to Portugal's news agency Lusa:
translation.yo: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé iṣẹ́ oníròyìn kan ti Orílẹ̀-èdè Portugal Lusa ti ròyìn:

translation.en: Translation Original Quote
translation.yo: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

translation.en: The two Cape Verdean mobile telecommunications operators, CV Móvel and Unitel T+, announced today a joint campaign that will make available a free package of 2,000 MB of internet to encourage citizens to stay at home, as a form of prevention of COVID-19.
translation.yo: Lónìí Ilé Iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ti Cape Verde méjèèjì, CV Móvel àti Unitel T+, ṣe ìfilọ̀ ìpolongo alájúmọ̀ṣe tí yóò mú kí MB ẹgbẹ̀rún 2 ó jẹ́ ti àwọn ará ìlú fún ìwúrí láti leè mú wọn dúró sílé lójúnà ìdíná ìtànká àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn COVID-19 láwùjọ.

translation.en: Titled the “Fica em Casa” (“stay home” in English) package, the promotion was announced by the two operators on social networks in a message that says they have “joined forces” so that Cape Verdeans stay “well at home”.
translation.yo: Tí àkọ́lée rẹ̀ jẹ́ “Fica em Casa” (“ẹ̀bùn ìdúró sílé” ní èdè Yorùbá), ìpolongo náà ni àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ méjèèjì gbé jáde sórí ẹ̀rọ agbọ́rọ̀káyé tí a kọ báyìí pé àwọ́n ti f'oríkorí láti “ṣiṣẹ́ àjàmọ̀ṣe” tí yóò mú kí àwọn ará orílẹ̀ Cape Verde “ó jókòó sílé”.

translation.en: The package offers customers of both operators, in addition to the 2,000 MB data package, 15 minutes of calls for all national operators to be used up until April 30.
translation.yo: Ẹ̀bùn pàtàkì yìí wà fún oníbàárà ilé iṣẹ́ méjèèjì, àti pé ní àfikún sí MB ẹgbẹ̀rún 2 tí wọ́n yóò fún wọn, owó ìpè ọ̀fẹ́ fún ìsẹ́jú 15 yóò wà lófò fún pípe èyíkéyìí òpó ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè náà tí ó sì gbọdọ̀ jẹ́ lílò kí ó tó d'ọjọ́ 30, Oṣù Kẹrin.

translation.en: COVID-19: Campaign gives 2000 MB of internet to help Cape Verdeans to stay home.
translation.yo: COVID-19: Ìpolongo àǹfààní ìrànwọ́ MB ẹgbẹ̀rún 2 láti mú kí àwọn ará ìlú Cape Verde ó jókòó kalé kí òfin kónílégbélé ó bá f'ẹsẹ̀rinlẹ̀.

translation.en: A few people have questioned the efficacy of such campaign as many Cape Verdeans don't have regular internet access:
translation.yo: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ará ìlú Cape Verde ti yọ ṣùtì ẹnu sí ìpolongo yìí, nítorí ségesège ni afẹ́fẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára náà máa ń ṣe:

translation.en: What a joke !!!
translation.yo: Àwàdà ńlá ni!!!

translation.en: How many Cape Verdeans have internet?
translation.yo: Ẹni mélòó nínú ará ìlú Cape Verde l'ó ní afẹ́fẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tó já geere?

translation.en: In Cape Verde, an island country of 560,000 people, 57 percent of the population use the internet, according to 2017 data by the World Bank.
translation.yo: Ní Cape Verde, agbègbè erékùṣù tí ó ní èèyàn tó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún 560, tí idà 57 wọn ń lo ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí tí Ilé Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ṣe ní ọdún 2017 ti ṣe fi hàn.

translation.en: On that year, the world average was 50 percent.
translation.yo: Lọ́dún náà, ìdá 50 ni ìdá àwọn tó ń lo ayélujára tó pọ̀jù lágbàáyé.

translation.en: In Mozambique, where internet penetration is even lower — the same World Bank report says only 10 percent of its 30 million people are internet users –, state-owned operator TmCel launched a similar promotion, with the same "stay home" slogan.
translation.yo: Ní Mozambique, níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn tí ó ń lo ayélujára ò ti tó nǹkan – Ilé Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé kan yìí náà fi hàn nínú ìwádìí pé ìdá 10 àwọn ará ìlú nínú èèyàn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ló ní ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára ní àrọ́wọ́tó – ilé iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ TmCel tí ó jẹ́ ti ọmọ onílùú náà ti se ìfilọ́lẹ̀ ìpolongo "kónílégbélé" yìí kan náà.

translation.en: The promotion consists of packages ranging from 1 to 5 GB, costing from 25 to 100 meticals (0.37 to 1.50 USD).
translation.yo: Ìpolongo náà kún fún àwọn ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àǹfààní ẹ̀bùn ọ̀fẹ́ láti GB 1 sí GB 5, tí owóo rẹ̀ jẹ́ 25 sí 100 meticals (0.37 sí 1.50 owó US).

translation.en: Activate the #StayAtHome offers from 25 meticals valid for 30 days.
translation.yo: Mú àǹfààní ẹ̀bùn #StayAtHome yìí lò fún 25 meticals láàárín oṣù kan.

translation.en: Use *219# choose your offer and stay at home with Tmcel. For more information visit the link below:
translation.yo: Tẹ *219# láti se àṣàyàn ẹ̀bùn tí ó fẹ́, kí o sì dúró sílé pẹ̀lú TmCel. Fún àlàyé lẹ́kùnúnrẹ́rẹ́ kàn sí:

translation.en: Although the offer seems to have been well received, a few Twitter users posed questions:
translation.yo: Bí-ó-ti-lẹ̀-jẹ́-pé àǹfààní ẹ̀bùn jẹ́ ohun àtẹ́wọ́ gbà láwùjọ, díẹ̀ lára àwọn òǹṣàmúlò gbàgede Twitter se àgbéjáde àwọn ìbéèrè kan:

translation.en: Good initiative.
translation.yo: Ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó dáa ni.

translation.en: Is the quality good too?
translation.yo: Sé ó jẹ́ ojúlówó bákan náà?

translation.en: Staying home is not an option for the many informal and daily subsistence workers in Mozambique and Cape Verde. Activist Tomás Queface tweeted:
translation.yo: Dídúró sílé yìí kì í se ohun tó bá àwọn onísẹ́ ọwọ́ àti oníṣẹ́ ìgbẹ́mìíró tí ó ń gbé ní Mozambique àti Cape Verde lára mú rárá. Ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọ-ènìyàn Tomás Queface túwíìtì:

translation.en: The #Coronavirus reveals yet another facet of social inequalities.
translation.yo: Àìsàn #coronavirus yìí ti ṣípayá ìwà àìdọ́gba tí ó wà láwùjọ wa.

translation.en: While #StayAtHome is a privilege for few people, for the poor it is a constant dilemma: staying at home without food, or continuing to work and risk your health or endangering the health of others.
translation.yo: Bí òfin kónílé ó gbélé #StayAtHome ṣe jẹ́ oore ọ̀fẹ́ fún àwọn kan, níṣe l'ó ń mú àwọn tí ò rọ́wọ́họrí láwùjọ fajúro látàrí fi f'ọwọ́ múkan: nínúu dídúró sílé láì rí oúnjẹ jẹ, tàbí ṣíṣiṣẹ́ kí àlàáfíà ara ó di fíafìa tàbí fífi ìlera àwọn ará ìlú tó kù wéwu.

translation.en: COVID-19 revives grim history of medical experimentation in Africa
translation.yo: COVID-19 ṣe àgbéǹde ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá tó burú jáì nípa ìdánwò egbògi ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀

translation.en: Africa isn't a testing lab'
translation.yo: Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ kì í ṣe iyàrá àyẹ̀wò'

translation.en: Sgt. 1st Class Marites Cabreza, a nurse with 354th Civil Affairs Brigade, Special Functioning Team, Combined Joint Task Force-Horn of Africa, tends to a patient March 29, 2008, during a medical civil action project in Goubetto, Djibouti.
translation.yo: Olóyè ọmọ-ogun. 1st Class Marites Cabreza, olùtọ́jú ọmọ tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú 354th Civil Affairs Brigade, Special Functioning Team, Combined Joint Task Force-Ìho Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, ń tọ́jú aláìsàn lọ́jọ́ 29, oṣù kẹta, ọdún-un 2008, lásìkò àkànṣe iṣẹ́ ìwòsàn ìlú ní Goubetto, Djibouti.

translation.en: Photo by US Air Force Tech. Sgt. Jeremy T. Lock. Public Domain.
translation.yo: Àwòrán láti àkàtà Ọmọ-ogún Òfuurufú US Ẹ̀ka ìmọ̀ ẹ̀rọ , Jeremy T. Lock. Ìlò gbogboògbò.

translation.en: Check out Global Voices’ special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19.
translation.yo: Yẹ àkànṣe ìròyìn-in ‘Ohùn Àgbáyé’ lórí ipa tí COVID-19 ń kó lágbàáyé.

translation.en: The mad rush by scientists and researchers to test potential treatments for COVID-19 in scientific trials has revived a heated debate over the use of humans in critical drug trials in Africa.
translation.yo: Arée pànpàlà bí o ò lọ ó yàgò tí ń ṣẹlẹ̀ láàárín àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ àti oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí kò ṣẹ̀yìn ìgbésẹ̀ láti ṣe àyẹ̀wò àwọn oògùn tí wọ́n rò pé ó lè wo àrùn COVID-19 sàn lára ọmọ ènìyàn ti ń dá gbọ́nmisíi-omi-ò-tóo sílẹ̀ ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

translation.en: On April 1, two French researchers, Dr. Jean-Paul Mira and Camille Locht, suggested on a live television broadcast that trials of a potential vaccine should first take place in Africa, according to Al Jazeera.
translation.yo: Lọ́jọ́ 1, oṣù kẹrin, àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí ọmọ ilẹ̀ Faransé méjì, Oníṣègùn Jean-Paul Mira, àti Camille Locht, dá a lábàá lórí ètò kan ní orí ẹ̀rọ-amóhùnmáwòrán wí pé Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ni ó yẹ kí wọn ó ti kókó dán egbògi àjẹsára tí yóò ká apá àrùn kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà sàn wò, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Al-Jazeera ti ṣe jíyìn ìròyìn náà.

translation.en: Dr. Mira, head of the intensive care unit at Cochin Hospital in Paris, compared the current situation to “certain AIDS studies, where among prostitutes, we try things because we know that they are highly exposed and don't protect themselves.”
translation.yo: Oníṣègùn Mira, olórí ẹ̀ka ìtọ́jú àfẹ́jù ti Cochin Hospital tí ó wà ní Paris, fi ọ̀rọ̀ náà wé “àwọn ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò fún Àrùn Kògbóògùn ÉÈDÌ, tí ó jẹ́ wí pé lára àwọn olówòo nàbì ni a ti kọ́kọ́ dán an wò, a gbìyànjú àwọn nǹkan kan nítorí a mọ̀ dájú wí pé wọn kì í dá ààbò bo ara wọn, àti pé ó rọrùn fún àrùn ìbálòpọ̀ láti lúgọ sí ara wọn.”

translation.en: The two researchers made these comments in the context of a discussion of trials in Europe and Australia to see if the BCG tuberculosis vaccine could be effective against the novel coronavirus.
translation.yo: Àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí méjèèjì mẹ́nu lọ́rọ́ nígbà tí àsọgbà ọ̀rọ̀ kan wáyé lórí ìṣàyẹ̀wò egbògi àjẹsára BCG fún ikọ́-àwúpẹ̀jẹ̀ ní Yúróòpù àti Australia láti mọ̀ bóyá yóò ṣiṣẹ́ ìwòsàn fún kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀.

translation.en: In Australia, trials are being conducted on at least 4,000 health care workers.
translation.yo: Ní Australia, àyẹ̀wò ti ń lọ lórí àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìlera ẹgbẹ̀rún 4.

translation.en: The attitude of these researchers echoes a long, grim history of medical experimentation and exploitation in Africa, where African leaders have colluded with pharmaceutical companies — often based in Europe or the United States — to conduct trials on the most vulnerable people in society.
translation.yo: Ìṣesí àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí wọ̀nyí jẹ́ gbohùngbohùn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdánwò àti fífọwọ́ọlá gbá ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ ní ojú, tí ó ṣe wí pé àwọn adarí Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti pàdí-àpò-pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn iléeṣẹ́ apooògùntà — tí ó fi Yúróòpù tàbí ilẹ̀ Amẹ́ríkà ṣe ibùgbé — láti wá ṣe àyẹ̀wò ní ara àwọn tí kò rí já jẹ láwùjọ.

translation.en: The researchers’ remarks immediately sparked condemnation and outrage, with the trending hashtag phrase, "Africans are not guinea pigs."
translation.yo: Lẹ́sẹ̀kẹsẹ̀ ni ìṣọ̀rọ̀sí àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí wọ̀nyí rí ìdálẹ́bi àti ìbínú àwọn ènìyàn, tí ó mú àpólà ọ̀rọ̀ kan, "Ọmọ ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ kì í ṣe eku ẹmọ́." gbajúmọ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ-agbọ́rọ̀káyé.

translation.en: Ivorian football star Didier Drogba tweeted:
translation.yo: Ìràwọ̀ agbábọ́ọ̀lù ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Ivory Coast Didier Drogba túwíìtì:

translation.en: By April 3, Dr. Mira had apologized for his comments, but only after major pushback and pressure from the France-based anti-racism group SOS Racisme. Dr. Locht’s employer, however, dismissed the outrage on Twitter as "fake news", saying that the remarks had been taken out of context.
translation.yo: Nígbà tí ó di ọjọ́ 3, Oṣù Kẹrin, Oníṣègùn Mira ti ṣe ìtọrọ àforíjì fún àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó sọ, àmọ́ lẹ́yìn tí àwọn ẹgbẹ́ SOS Racisme kọ ẹ̀yìn sí i ni ó ṣe èyí. Òṣìṣẹ́ẹ oníṣègùn Locht, bákan náà, da àwọn ẹ̀hónú orí Twitter dànù gẹ́gẹ́ bí i "ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ́ ", nítorí wí pé àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ náà kò rí bí wọ́n ti ṣe ń sọ ọ́.

translation.en: That same week, Congolese virologist Jean-Jacque Muyembe, who worked on the frontlines of the Ebola epidemic in Democratic Republic of Congo, announced that DR Congo "is prepared to take part in testing of any future vaccine against the coronavirus", according to News 24.
translation.yo: Ní àárín ọ̀sẹ̀ yẹn kan náà, onímọ̀ nípa àrùn àìfojúrí ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Congo Jean-Jacque Muyembe, tí ó ń léwájú nínú ìgbógunti àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn ibà ìdà ẹ̀jẹ̀ Ebola ní orílẹ̀-èdè Ìlú Ìjọba Àwaarawa Olómìnira Congo, filọ̀ wí pé DR Congo "ti ṣe tán láti kópa nínú irúfẹ́ ìdánwò egbògi tí yóò pa kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà tí kò bá à wáyé lọ́jọ́ iwájú", bí News 24 ti jábọ̀.

translation.en: Muyembe, the head of the nation’s pandemic task force and national health institute, told a news conference:
translation.yo: Muyembe, olórí ìgbìmọ̀ amúṣẹ́ṣe lórí àjàkáyé àrùn náà àti Iléeṣẹ́ ètò ìlera orílẹ̀-èdè náà, sọ níbi àpérò àwọn oníròyìn kan:

translation.en: We've been chosen to conduct these tests...
translation.yo: Wọ́n ti yàn wá láti ṣe àwọn àyẹ̀wò wọ̀nyí...

translation.en: The vaccine will be produced in the United States, or in Canada, or in China.
translation.yo: Ìlú Ìṣọ̀kan Amẹ́ríkà tàbí Canada tàbí ní China ni a ó ti ṣe egbògi àjẹsára náà.

translation.en: We're candidates for doing the testing here.
translation.yo: Àwa ni ẹni ayàn fún iṣẹ́ àyẹ̀wò náà níbí.

translation.en: Once again, the remarks drew ire from Congolese citizens and netizens around the world condemning Dr. Muyembe’s openness to hosting clinical trials in DR Congo, where the rates of infection for COVID-19 are still relatively low.
translation.yo: Lẹ́ẹ̀kan sí i, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí fa ìrúnú àwọn ọmọ Congo àti àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára jákèjádò ilé ayé tí wọ́n dá Oníṣègùn Muyembe ní ẹ̀bí nítorí ó faramọ́ ìṣàyẹ̀wò egbògi ní DR Congo, níbi tí iye àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19 kò tí ì fi bẹ́ẹ̀ pọ̀.

translation.en: Within hours, Dr. Muyembe clarified his statements in a video message, confirming that the vaccine would only be trialed in DR Congo after it had been done in countries such as the US and China:
translation.yo: Láàárín wákàtí díẹ̀, Oníṣègùn Muyembe yànnàná ọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ̀ nínú àwòrán-àtohùn kan, tí ó fi ìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ wí pé ó di ìgbà tí wọ́n bá ti kọ́kọ́ yẹ iṣẹ́ egbògi náà wò ní US àti China ni yóò tó jẹ́ lílò ní DR Congo:

translation.en: A grim history of medical experiment in Africa
translation.yo: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá tó burú jáì nípa ìdánwò egbògi ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀

translation.en: Medical experimentation in Africa — often conducted under the guise of the "greater good" and of finding cures for deadly diseases like meningitis and HIV/AIDS — has sounded ethical and moral alarm bells for years — particularly over informed consent and forced medical procedures.
translation.yo: Ìdánwò egbògi ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ — tí ó sábà máa ń wáyé lábẹ́ ẹ̀tàn "ìfẹ́ẹ gbogboògbò” tí ó pọn dandan ní ojúnà àti wá ìwòsàn fún àrùn aṣekúpani bí i àrùn yírùnyírùn àti àrùn kògbóògùn HIV/AIDS — ti lu agogo ìtanijí ìwà-ọmọlúwàbí fún àìníye ọdún — pàápàá jù lọ lórí ìgbàṣẹ lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn kí wọn ó tó ṣe ìdánwò àti ìlànà ìṣètò ìlera onítúláàsì.

translation.en: These trials are often funded by leading health organizations like the World Health Organization, the United States’ Centers for Disease Control and the National Institute of Health.
translation.yo: Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ tí ó jẹ́ asíwájú nínú ètò ìlera lágbàáyé bí i Àjọ Elétò Ìlera Àgbáyé, Àjọ Aṣàkóso Àrùn ti orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà àti Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Ìlera Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ ni ó máa ń kó owó sílẹ̀ fún irú àwọn iṣẹ́ báyìí.

translation.en: In Zimbabwe, in the 1990s, over 17,000 HIV-positive women were tested without informed consent in trials for the anti-retroviral drug AZT funded by the CDC, WHO and the NIH.
